    Notwithstanding any other provision of this article, smoking is prohibited in any portion of the living quarters, including, but not limited to, sleeping rooms, dining areas, restrooms, laundry areas, lobbies, and hallways, of a building used in whole or in part as a student dormitory that is owned and operated or otherwise utilized by a public or private institution of higher education. 
(Code 2008, § 9.130; Ord. No. 08-02, § 1, 2-4-2008) 
Sec. 38-24. - Designation of other nonsmoking areas. 
    Notwithstanding any other provision of this article, any employer, owner, occupant, lessee, operator, manager, or other person in control of any public place or place of employment may designate a non-enclosed area of a public place or place of employment, including outdoor areas, as an area where smoking is also prohibited provided that such employer, owner, lessee or occupant shall conspicuously post signs prohibiting smoking in the manner described in section 38-22(a) and (b). 
(Code 2008, § 9.140; Ord. No. 08-02, § 1, 2-4-2008) 
Sec. 38-25. - Exemptions. 
    Notwithstanding any other provision of this article, smoking is allowed in the following areas: 
(1)  Private residences or dwelling places, except when used as a child care, adult day care, or healthcare facility or any other home based business open to the public. 
(2)  Retail tobacco stores, as defined in section 38-19, in operation prior to the effective date of the amendatory act of the 95th General Assembly. The retail tobacco store shall annually file with the department by January 31 an affidavit stating the percentage of its gross income during the prior calendar year that was derived from the sale of loose tobacco, plants, or herbs and cigars, cigarettes, pipes, or other smoking devices for smoking tobacco and related smoking accessories. Any retail tobacco store that begins operation after the effective date of the state amendatory act may only qualify for an exemption if located in a freestanding structure occupied solely by the business and smoke from the business does not migrate into an enclosed area where smoking is prohibited. 
(3)  Hotel and motel sleeping rooms that are rented to guests and are designated as smoking rooms, provided that all smoking rooms on the same floor must be contiguous and smoke from these rooms must not infiltrate into nonsmoking rooms or other areas where smoking is prohibited. Not more than 25 percent of the rooms rented to guests in a hotel or motel may be designated as rooms where smoking is allowed. The status of rooms as smoking or nonsmoking may not be changed, except to add additional nonsmoking rooms. 
(4)  Enclosed laboratories that are excluded from the definition of "place of employment" in section 38-19. 
(5)  Common smoking rooms in long-term care facilities operated under the authority of the state department of veterans' affairs or licensed under the Nursing Home Care Act that are accessible only to residents who are smokers and have requested in writing to have access to the common smoking room where smoking is permitted and the smoke shall not infiltrate other areas of the long-term care facility. 
(Code 2008, § 9.150; Ord. No. 08-02, § 1, 2-4-2008) 
Sec. 38-26. - Enforcement; complaints. 
(a)  The city police department shall enforce the provisions of this article and may impose fines pursuant to section 1-8. 
(b)  Any person may register a complaint with the city police department, or a state-certified local public health department for violation of this article. The department shall establish a telephone number that a person may call to register a complaint under this subsection. 
(Code 2008, § 9.160; Ord. No. 08-02, § 1, 2-4-2008) 
Sec. 38-27. - Injunctions. 
    The city shall have the right to institute a circuit court action to enjoin repeated violations of this article. 
(Code 2008, § 9.180; Ord. No. 08-02, § 1, 2-4-2008) 
Sec. 38-28. - Discrimination prohibited. 
    No individual may be discriminated against in any manner because of the exercise of any rights afforded by this article. 
(Code 2008, § 9.190; Ord. No. 08-02, § 1, 2-4-2008) 
Chapter 42 - NUISANCES 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 42-1. - Failure to maintain enclosures for domestic animals; fine. 
    If any owner or occupant of any premises in the city permits any stable, pen, or place where any domestic animals or fowls are kept upon such premises to become nauseous, foul, offensive, or injurious to the public health or to his neighbors, he shall be subject to a fine of $50.00 in each and every case, for every day the same continues after such notice to abate and remove such nuisance. 
(Code 2008, § 8.20.010; Ord. No. 4, div. 3, § 10, 1912) 
Sec. 42-2. - Electric fences unlawful. 
    It is unlawful for any person, firm, or corporation to maintain any type of electric fence or electrified fence through which an electric current flows, whether powered by battery or generated electricity, for any purpose within the city limits. The maintenance and/or operation of an electric fence of any type is a nuisance. 
(Code 2008, § 8.20.030; Ord. No. 299, § 2, 1959) 
Sec. 42-3. - Excessive noise; prohibited; defined. 
(a)  No person, firm or corporation shall create excessive noise within the corporate limits of the city, by the use of any instrumentality whatsoever. 
(b)  No person, firm or corporation shall permit to operate any instrumentality which causes excessive noise within the corporate limits of the city. 
(c)  The term "excessive noise" means that noise which restricts in an unreasonable way the quiet, peaceful enjoyment of any citizen of the city upon his own premises, which includes, but is not limited to, the following acts: 
(1)  Blowing horns. The sounding of any horn or signal device for an unnecessary or unreasonable period of time. 
(2)  Radios, musical instruments, etc. The playing of any radio, musical instrument, loud speaker or amplifier, between the hours of 8:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. 
(3)  Yelling, shouting, hooting, etc. Yelling, shouting, hooting, whistling or singing between the hours of 8:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. 
(4)  Pets. The keeping of any animal, bird or fowl which causes noise for an unnecessary or unreasonable period of time. 
(5)  Building operations. The erection, excavation, demolition, alteration or repair of any building, streets or public places in a residential area between the hours of 8:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m., except in the case of emergencies in the interest of public health and safety. 
(6)  Operation of ATVs, motorcycles, snowmobiles, lawnmowers, etc. The operation of any all-terrain vehicle, off-highway motorcycle, snowmobile, lawnmower or stationary internal combustion engine between the hours of 8:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m., except when: 
a.  Such vehicle or engine is being used for public utility purposes, including, but not limited to, snow removal, agriculture, towing of other vehicles, and inspection of public works; 
b.  Such vehicles or engines are used by law enforcement officers for law enforcement purposes; or 
c.  There is an emergency. 
(d)  It shall not be a violation of this section for any person, firm or corporation, licensed to do business in the city, to create such noise resulting from said business' regular and customary business activities during its normal business hours. Any person, firm or corporation, licensed to do business in the city, that desires to conduct a special event or conduct business outside of its normal business hours must obtain written permission from the city to conduct such activities. Nor shall it be a violation of this section to create such noise resulting from a city sponsored event or other special event which has obtained written permission from the city to conduct such event or activities. 
(Code 2008, § 8.20.050; Ord. No. 2-79, §§ 1-3, 1979; Ord. No. 16-10, § 2, 10-3-2016) 
Sec. 42-4. - Excessive fumes; prohibited; defined. 
(a)  No person, firm or corporation shall operate any instrumentality which causes excessive fumes within the corporate limits of the city. 
(b)  No person, firm or corporation shall permit to be operated any instrumentality which causes excessive fumes within the corporate limits of the city. 
(c)  The term "excessive fumes" means that amount of fumes which unreasonably endangers the physical health of a citizen of the city upon his own premises as determined by the county health department. Excessive fumes shall include any substance or thing emitting or causing any foul, offensive, nauseous, noxious or injurious odor or stench which annoys, discomforts or endangers the welfare, health or safety of any person within the city. 
(Code 2008, § 8.20.060; Ord. No. 2-79, §§ 4, 5, 1979) 
Secs. 42-5-42-26. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CHRONIC NUISANCE PROPERTIES 

Sec. 42-27. - Abatement of chronic nuisance properties. 
(a)  Any certain property within the city which becomes a chronic nuisance property is in violation of this article and is subject to its remedies. 
(b)  Any person in charge who permits property under his ownership or control to be a chronic nuisance property shall be in violation of this article and subject to its remedies. 
(Code 2008, § 8.20.080; Ord. No. 12-08, § I, 6-4-2012) 
Sec. 42-28. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Chronic nuisance property means property upon which three or more of the behaviors listed below have occurred during any 60-day period, as a result of any three separate factual events that have been independently investigated by any law enforcement agency: 
(1)  Disorderly conduct as defined in 720 ILCS 5/26-1. 
(2)  Unlawful use of weapons as defined in 720 ILCS 5/24-1 et seq. 
(3)  Mob action as defined in 720 ILCS 5/25-1. 
(4)  Discharge of a firearm as defined in 720 ILCS 5/24-1.2 and 5/24-1.5. 
(5)  Gambling as defined in 720 ILCS 5/28-1. 
(6)  Possession, manufacture or delivery of controlled substance as defined in 720 ILCS 570/401 et seq. 
(7)  Assault or battery or any related offense as defined in 720 ILCS 5/12-1 et seq. 
(8)  Sexual abuse or related offenses as defined in 720 ILCS 5/12-15 et seq. 
(9)  Public indecency as defined in 720 ILCS 5/11-9 et seq. 
(10)  Prostitution as defined in 720 ILCS 5/11-14 et seq. 
(11)  Criminal damage to property as defined in 720 ILCS 5/21-1 et seq. 
(12)  Possession, cultivation, manufacture or delivery of cannabis as defined in 720 ILCS 550/1 et seq. 
(13)  Illegal consumption or possession of alcohol as defined in 235 ILCS 5/1 et seq. 
(14)  Violation of the city property maintenance code (article IV of this chapter). 
(15)  Violation of any city ordinance or state statute controlling or regulating the sale or use of alcoholic beverages. 
    Control means the ability to regulate, restrain, dominate, counteract or govern conduct that occurs on that property. 
    Owner means any person, agent, firm or corporation having any legal or equitable interest in the property. The term "owner" includes, but is not limited to: 
(1)  A mortgage in possession in whom is vested: 
a.  All or part of the legal title to the property; 
b.  All or part of the beneficial ownership and the right to the present use and enjoyment of the premises; 
(2)  An occupant who can control what occurs on the property. 
    Permit means to suffer, allow, consent to, acquiesce by failure to prevent, or expressly ascent or agree to the doing of an act. 
    Person means any natural person, association, partnership or corporation capable of owning or using property in the city. 
    Person in charge means any person in actual or constructive possession of a property, including, but not limited to, an owner, occupant of property under his domain, ownership or control. 
    Property means any real property, including land in that which is affixed, incidental or pertinent to land, including, but not limited to, any premises, room, house, building, or structure or any separate part or portion thereof, whether permitted or not. 
(Code 2008, § 8.20.080; Ord. No. 97-38, § 2, 6-16-1997; Ord. No. 12-08, § I, 6-4-2012) 
Sec. 42-29. - Remedy. 
(a)  In the event a court determines property to be a chronic nuisance property, the court may order that the property be closed and secured against all use and occupancy for a period of not less than 30 days, but not more than 180 days, or the court may employ any other remedy deemed by it to be appropriate to abate the nuisance. 
(b)  In addition to the remedy provided in subsection (a) of this section, the court may impose upon the owner of the property a civil penalty in accordance with section 1-8, payable to the city, for each day the owner had actual knowledge that the property was a chronic nuisance property and permitted the property to remain chronic nuisance property. 
(c)  In determining what remedy or remedies shall employ, the court may consider evidence of other conduct which has occurred on the property, including, but not limited to: 
(1)  The disturbance of neighbors. 
(2)  The recurrence of loud and obnoxious noises. 
(3)  Repeated consumption of alcohol in public. 
(4)  The repeated sale or possession of controlled substances on the premises. 
(Code 2008, § 8.20.080; Ord. No. 12-08, § I, 6-4-2012) 
Sec. 42-30. - Abatement of nuisance. 
    The corporation counsel of the city or the state's attorney of the county may commence an action to abate public nuisance as described above. Upon being satisfied by affidavits or other sworn evidence that an alleged chronic nuisance exists, the court may without notice or bond enter a temporary restraining order or preliminary injunction to enjoin any defendant from maintaining such nuisance and may enter an order restraining any defendant from removing or interfering with all property used in connection with the chronic nuisance. 
(Code 2008, § 8.20.080; Ord. No. 12-08, § I, 6-4-2012) 
Sec. 42-31. - Procedure. 
    When the chief of police of the city receives two or more police reports documenting the occurrence of any chronic nuisance activity, as described above ("nuisance activity") on or within a property, the chief of police shall independently review such reports to determine whether they describe criminal acts. Upon such findings, the chief may: 
(1)  Notify the person in charge in writing that the property is in danger of becoming a chronic nuisance property. The notice shall contain the following information: 
a.  The street address or a legal description sufficient for identification of the property. 
b.  A statement that the chief of police has information that the property may be chronic nuisance property, with a concise description of the nuisance activities that may exist, or that have occurred. The chief of police shall offer the person in charge an opportunity to propose a course of action that the chief of police agrees will abate the nuisance activities giving rise to the violation. 
c.  Demand that the person in charge respond to the chief of police within ten days to discuss the nuisance activities. 
(2)  After complying with the notification procedures described herein when the chief of police receives a police report documenting the occurrence of a third nuisance activity at or within a property and determines that the property has become a chronic nuisance property, the chief of police shall: 
a.  Notify the person in charge in writing that the property has been determined to be a chronic nuisance property. The notice shall contain the following information: 
1.  The street address or legal description sufficient for identification of the property. 
2.  A statement that the chief of police has determined the property to be chronic nuisance property with a concise description of the nuisance activities leading to his findings. 
3.  Demand that the person in charge respond within ten days to the chief of police and propose a course of action that the chief of police agrees will abate the nuisance activities giving rise to the violation. 
4.  Service shall be made either personally or by first class mail, postage pre-paid, return receipt requested, addressed to the person in charge at the address of the property believed to be a chronic nuisance property, or such other place which is likely to give the person in charge notice of the determination by the chief of police. 
5.  A copy of the notice shall be served on the owner at such address as shown on the tax rolls of the county in which the property is located, and/or the occupant, at the address of the property, if these persons are different than the person in charge, and shall be made either personally or by first class mail, postage pre-paid. 
6.  A copy of the notice shall also be posted at the property after ten days has elapsed from the service or mailing of the notice to the person in charge and the person in charge has not contacted the chief of police. 
7.  The failure of any person to receive notice that the property may be a chronic nuisance property shall not invalidate or otherwise affect the proceedings under this article. 
b.  If after the notification, but prior to the commencement of legal proceedings by the city pursuant to this article, a person in charge stipulates with the chief of police that the person in charge will pursue a course of action the parties agree will abate the nuisance activities giving rise to the violation, the chief of police may agree to postpone legal proceedings for a period of not less than ten nor more than 30 days, except in the case of a nuisance activity under subsection (2)a.7 of this section where a search warrant was executed at the property. If the agreed course of action does not result in the abatement of the nuisance activity or if no agreement concerning abatement is reached within 30 days, the chief of police shall request authorization for the corporation counsel to commence a legal proceeding to abate the nuisance. 
c.  Concurrent with the notification producers set forth herein, the chief of police shall send copies of the notice, as well as, any other documentation which supports legal proceedings to the corporation counsel. 
(3)  When a person in charge makes a response to the chief of police as required above, any conduct or statements made in connection with the furnishing of that response shall not constitute an admission that any nuisance activities have or are occurring. This subsection does not require the exclusion of any evidence which is otherwise admissible or offered for any other purpose. 
(Code 2008, § 8.20.080; Ord. No. 12-08, § I, 6-4-2012) 
Sec. 42-32. - Commencement of action, burden of proof. 
(a)  In an action seeking closure of a chronic nuisance property, the city shall have the initial burden of showing by preponderance of the evidence that the property is a chronic nuisance property. 
(b)  It is a defense to an action seeking the closure of chronic nuisance property that the owner of the property at the time in question could not, in the exercise of reasonable care or diligence, determine that the property had become a chronic nuisance property, or could not, in spite of the exercise of reasonable care and diligence, control the conduct leading of the findings that the property is a chronic nuisance property. 
(c)  In establishing the amount of any civil penalty requested, the court may consider any of the following factors if they need be found appropriate, and shall site those found applicable: 
(1)  The action or lack of action taken by the person in charge to mitigate or correct the problem at the property. 
(2)  Whether the problem at the property was repeated or continuous. 
(3)  The magnitude or gravity of the problem. 
(4)  The cooperation of the person in charge with the city. 
(5)  The cost of the city investigating and correcting or attempting to correct the condition. 
(Code 2008, § 8.20.080; Ord. No. 12-08, § I, 6-4-2012) 
Secs. 42-33-42-52. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - ACCUMULATIONS ON PROPERTY 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 42-53-42-77. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - WEEDS 

Sec. 42-78. - Weeds declared a nuisance. 
    Any weeds on the following list, found growing in any lot or tract of land in the city are hereby declared to be a nuisance, and it shall be unlawful to permit any such weeds to grow or remain on any such place: Annual Ragweed ( Ambrosia artemixiifolia ), Giant Ragweed ( Ambrosia trifida ), Carly Dock ( Rumex crispus ), Johnsongrass ( Sorghum halepense ), Canadian Thistle ( Cirsium arvense ), Musk Thistle ( Carduus nutans ), Bull Thistle ( Cirsium vulgare ), Lambsquarters ( Chenopodium album ), Multiflora Rose ( Rosa multiflora ), Red Clover ( Trifolium pratense ), Yellow Sweet Clover ( Melilotus officinalis ), Pigweed Amaranth ( Amaranthus retroflexus ), Rough Cocklebur (X anthium strumarium ) and all other noxious weeds as defined by the statutes of the state. 
(Code 2008, § 8.28.010; Ord. No. 4-95(part), 1995; Ord. No. 15-20, § I, 12-7-2015) 
Sec. 42-79. - Height. 
    It shall be unlawful to permit any weeds, grass or plants other than trees, bushes, flowers, vegetables, ornamentals, or native plants that are not considered noxious weeds by the state, to grow to a height exceeding eight inches anywhere in the city and any such plants or weed exceeding such height are declared to be a nuisance. All plants which are permitted to grow within the city must be managed and well maintained to a standard of good care taking according to the purpose of the plants that are grown. 
(Code 2008, § 8.28.020; Ord. No. 4-95(part), 1995; Ord. No. 15-20, § I, 12-7-2015) 
Sec. 42-80. - Growth prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any party owning, leasing, occupying, controlling, or responsible for any lot or parcel of land within the city limits to permit growth as prohibited in section 42-79 between the property line of such lot or parcel of land and the curb of any adjoining alley, street, public way or highway. 
(Code 2008, § 8.28.030; Ord. No. 4-95(part), 1995) 
Sec. 42-81. - Authority to abate. 
    In the event any property is in violation of this division, the city may, at its discretion, cut any weeds, grass, or plants, other than trees, bushes, flowers, vegetables or other ornamental plants and assess the cost to the owner of the property and file a lien against the property as provided in this division. 
(Code 2008, § 8.28.040; Ord. No. 4-95(part), 1995) 
Sec. 42-82. - Abatement lien. 
    If the city has abated the nuisance, the costs thereof shall be recoverable from the owner and the city may place a lien on the land until payment is made. Within 60 days after the cost and expense is incurred by the city or the party performing the service by the authority of the city, the city in the name of the party performing the service or in the city's name, may file a notice of lien in the office of the recorder of deeds of the county. The notice shall consist of a sworn statement setting out: 
(1)  A description of the real estate sufficient for identification thereof; 
(2)  The amount of money representing the cost and expense incurred or payable for the service; and 
(3)  The date when such cost and expenses were incurred by the city. 
(Code 2008, § 8.28.050; Ord. No. 4-95(part), 1995) 
Sec. 42-83. - Payment and release. 
    Upon payment of the cost and expense by the owner of or persons interested in such property after the notice of lien has been filed, the lien shall be released by the city or person whose name the lien was filed. The release may be filed as recorded in the city filing notice of lien; provided, however, no lien shall be released until the total cost and expense including the actual cost, filing fees and other costs of administration and interest are satisfied by payment in full. 
(Code 2008, § 8.28.060; Ord. No. 4-95(part), 1995) 
Secs. 42-84-42-109. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - GARBAGE, REFUSE AND ASHES[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal disposal of refuse, garbage and ashes, 65 ILCS 5/11-19-1 et seq.; Local Solid Waste Disposal Act, 415 ILCS 10/1 et seq.; Solid Waste Planning and Recycling Act, 415 ILCS 15/1 et seq.; Illinois Solid Waste Management Act, 415 ILCS 20/1 et seq.; land pollution and refuse disposal, 415 ILCS 5/20 et seq.; used tire disposal, 415 ILCS 5/53 et seq.; Litter Control Act, 415 ILCS 105/1 et seq.; open dumping, etc., of waste, 415 ILCS 5/21 et seq.; littering highways, 625 ILCS 5/11-1413. 

Sec. 42-110. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Ashes means residue from fires used for cooking and for heating buildings. 
    Garbage means wastes, resulting from the handling, preparation, cooking and consumption of food; or wastes from handling and sale of produce. 
    Refuse means combustible trash, including, but not limited to, paper, cartons, boxes, barrels, wood, excelsior, tree branches, yard trimmings, wood furniture, bedding, noncombustible trash, including, but not limited to, metals, tin cans, metal furniture, dirt, small quantities of rock and pieces of concrete, glass crockery, other mineral wastes, street rubbish, including, but not limited to, street sweepings, dirt, leaves, catch-basin dirt, contents of litter receptacles. The term "refuse" does not mean earth and waste from building operations, nor shall it include solid wastes resulting from industrial processes and manufacturing operations such as food processing wastes, boiler-house cinders, lumber, scraps and shavings. 
(Code 2008, § 5.17.010; Ord. No. 4-95(part), 1995) 
Sec. 42-111. - Accumulation prohibited and declared a nuisance. 
    The owner, occupant, or lessee of any premises in the city shall remove from said premises all garbage, refuse, and ashes from the premises at least once each week as nearly as practical, and any garbage, refuse, and ashes that are not so removed is hereby declared a nuisance. 
(Code 2008, § 5.17.020; Ord. No. 4-95(part), 1995) 
Sec. 42-112. - Notices. 
    The chief of police shall cause notice of any violations of this division to be made by registered letter demanding abatement of the nuisance or violation within seven days. 
(Code 2008, § 5.17.030; Ord. No. 4-95(part), 1995) 
Sec. 42-113. - Abatement, lien. 
    If the nuisance is not abated within seven days of the mailing of such notice, the city may cause the nuisance to be abated and the costs thereof to be collected from the owners of the land. If all costs are not paid within 60 days of the date the cost and expense is incurred, the city or the party performing the service by authority of the city, in his or its own name, may file a notice of lien in the office of the recorder of deeds of the county. The notice shall consist of a sworn statement setting out: 
(1)  A description of the real estate sufficient for identification thereof. 
(2)  The amount of money representing the cost and expense incurred or payable for the service. 
(3)  The date when such cost and expense was incurred by the city. The lien may be enforced by proceedings to foreclose as in case of mortgages or mechanic's liens. Suit to foreclose this lien shall be commenced within the two years after the date of filing notice of lien. 
(Code 2008, § 5.17.040; Ord. No. 4-95(part), 1995) 
Sec. 42-114. - Prior liens. 
    The lien shall not be valid as to any purchaser whose rights in and to such real estate have arisen subsequent to removal of the garbage and debris and prior to the filing of such notice, and the lien of such municipality shall not be valid as to any mortgages, judgment creditor or other lien or whose rights in and to such real estate arise prior to the filing of such notice. 
(Code 2008, § 5.17.050; Ord. No. 4-95(part), 1995) 
Sec. 42-115. - Payment and release. 
    Upon payment of the cost and expense by the owner or persons interested in such property after notice of the lien has been filed and the release may be filed, the lien shall be released by the city or person in whose name notice of lien; provided, however, no lien shall be released until the total cost and expense including the actual costs, filing fees and other costs of administration and interest are satisfied by payment in full. 
(Code 2008, § 5.17.060; Ord. No. 4-95(part), 1995) 
Secs. 42-116-42-143. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - MAINTENANCE OF PRIVATE PROPERTY[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal powers as to nuisances, 65 ILCS 5/11-60-2; nuisances generally, 720 ILCS 5/47-25; municipal sanitation code violations, 65 ILCS 5/11-19.2-1 et seq.; acts constituting public nuisances, 740 ILCS 55/221; Abandoned Refrigerator Act, 720 ILCS 505/0.01; Litter Control Act, 415 ILCS 105/1 et seq.; Environmental Protection Act, 415 ILCS 5/1 et seq. 

Sec. 42-144. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Nuisance means any condition or use of premises or building exteriors which is detrimental to the property of others or which causes or tends to cause substantial diminution in the value of other property in the neighborhood in which such premises are located. The term "nuisance" includes, but is not limited to, the keeping or depositing on, or the scattering over the premises of any of the following: 
(1)  Lumber, junk, trash, or debris. 
(2)  Abandoned, discarded or unused objects or equipment such as automobiles or parts, furniture, stoves, refrigerators, freezers, cans, containers, or building materials such as windows, cement blocks, piping, or wiring. 
(3)  Any compost pile which is of such a nature as to spread or harbor disease, emit unpleasant odors or harmful gases, or attract rodents, vermin, or other disease-carrying pests, animals or insects, provided that the presence of earthworms in a compost pile shall not constitute a nuisance. 
(4)  Unsanitary, deleterious or septic material kept upon any premises, unless such material is retained in containers or vessels which deny access to humans, flies, insects, rodents, or animals. 
(5)  Weeds such as jimson, burdock, ragweed, thistle, cocklebur, or other weeds of the like kind. 
(6)  Weeds, grasses, or plants, other than trees, bushes, flowers, or other ornamental plants exceeding eight inches in height anywhere in the city. 
(7)  Abandoned motor vehicles or motor vehicles with expired license or inoperative motor vehicles and equipment. 
(8)  Sounds, animals or any other things which interfere with the peace and comfort, or disturbs the quiet of any person in the city. 
(9)  Anything which is made, permitted, used, kept, maintained or operated, or any building or any animal that is kept in the city or outside of the city but within 11/2 miles of its limits, in a manner that is offensive, injurious or dangerous to the health of individuals or the public. 
(10)  Tanneries, soap factories, tallow chandleries, bone factories, or the steaming, boiling or rendering of tainted lard, tallow, offal, or other unwholesome animal substance within the city limits and within 11/2 miles thereof, without first having obtained such permission to conduct or carry on any such business. 
(11)  Discharging, placing, throwing or permitting to be discharged, or to flow from or out of any house or premises, any filthy, foul, or offensive matter or liquid of any kind, into any street, alley, or public place, or upon any adjacent lot or ground within the city. 
(12)  Any other condition dangerous to health; offensive to community moral standards, unlawfully obstructing the public in the free use of public property; or behavior which unreasonably interferes with the health, safety, peace, comfort or convenience of the general community. 
(13)  Causing, allowing, or permitting stormwater, surface water, groundwater, runoff water, subsurface drainage water or the like to be discharged into the sanitary sewer system of the city, by way of downspouts, footing tile, or otherwise, or allowing or permitting the same to be done by any person connected with the premises, under his control, thereby contributing to the backup, surcharge, overflow, or discharge of said sanitary sewer system into or onto the premises of another, or causing or tending to cause substantial diminution in the value of other property in the neighborhood in which such premises are located. 
The various nuisances described and enumerated in this section shall not be deemed to be exclusive, but shall be in addition to all other nuisances prescribed or prohibited by this Code and those offenses known to the common law or to the statutes of this state as nuisances. 
(Code 2008, § 15.04.010; Ord. No. 07-19, 12-3-2007) 
Sec. 42-145. - Duty of maintenance of private property. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person owning, leasing, occupying, or having charge of any premises to maintain or keep any nuisance thereon, or to keep or maintain such premises in a manner causing substantial devaluation in the value of the other property located in the neighborhood in which such premises are located. To prevent the devaluation of other property, the following minimum standards must be met at all times, including, but not limited, to the following: 
(1)  Foundations, exterior walls and roofs. Every foundation, exterior wall and roof of every building shall be substantially weathertight, and rodentproof; shall be kept in sound condition and good repair; shall be kept free of holes or breaks and of loose or rotting boards, timbers, bricks, stones and other structural material; and shall be safe to use and capable of supporting the load which normal use may cause to be placed thereon. 
(2)  Exterior surfaces. All exterior surfaces of any building shall be reasonably capable of withstanding the effects of the elements and decay. Any exterior surface which is deteriorated, decaying, disintegrating or which has lost its capability to reasonably withstand the effects of the elements shall be replaced. 
(3)  Windows and exterior doors. Every window, exterior door, basement or cellar door and hatchway shall be generally weathertight and rodentproof; shall be equipped with all appropriate hardware; shall be capable of being easily opened unless designed to be fixed; and all windows; exterior doors and screens shall be kept in good repair. 
(4)  Stairways and porches. Every inside and outside stairway and porch and every appurtenance thereto shall be maintained in a good state of repair and free from rotting, loose, or deteriorating supports, rails, floors and stairs so as to be safe to use and capable of supporting the loads that normal use may cause to be placed thereon. 
(5)  Accessory structures. All garages, tool sheds and all other accessory structures shall be kept in good repair so as not to be unsafe or a harbor for rats and other rodents. Fences and roadside mailboxes shall be maintained in good repair, solid and in the same condition required for other exterior surfaces. If attached to the exterior of a building, a television antenna shall be firmly and securely fastened to the building and shall be maintained in good repair. No television antenna shall be attached to any tree located on public property. 
(6)  Driveways and walkways. Cement or asphalt driveways and parking areas shall be maintained free of loose or broken material, cracks which are safety hazards and such driveways and parking areas shall be repaired as necessary to avoid safety hazards. Stone driveways, walkways and parking areas shall be maintained in forms designed to prevent the spread of gravel to public ways, easements and adjoining private property. 
(7)  Gutters, downspouts and sump pumps. All gutters, downspouts and sump pump discharge pipes shall be maintained free of debris which might prevent their proper functioning and shall not be allowed to discharge in a manner which might create unnecessary erosion. Downspouts shall discharge onto open vegetated areas to the greatest extent practicable and direct connection to sump pump laterals shall be avoided. No discharge pipes shall cut through existing street curbs, nor shall pipes discharge to the ground surface within ten feet of a roadway or sidewalk, unless discharge enters a ditch without flowing over paved surfaces. Pump discharge piping shall utilize a lateral connection to the storm sewer wherever practicable. All gutters and downspouts shall be securely fastened to the building which they serve. 
(8)  Ingress and egress. The means of ingress to and egress from any building, including, but not limited to, hallways, corridors, stairs and porches, shall be maintained in good repair and free from any obstructions. 
(9)  Protective railings. Any handrails, guardrails or other types of protective railings required to be constructed or installed under any provision of this Code or which have otherwise been constructed and installed shall be maintained in good repair. 
(Code 2008, § 15.04.020; Ord. No. 4-95(part), 1995; Ord. No. 07-19, 12-3-2007; Ord. No. 14-10, § I, 10-6-2014) 
Sec. 42-146. - Impermissible discharges into sanitary sewer system; abatement and other remedies. 
(a)  When the existence of a violation of section 74-194 is brought to the attention of the city administrator, he shall cause an inspection and investigation to be made by the appropriate agencies to determine whether abatement is necessary. 
(b)  The city administrator, or any employee duly authorized by him, shall be permitted access to any part of any property where access is necessary for the purpose of inspecting, observing, measuring, sampling, or testing to determine compliance with the provisions of section 74-194. If any person should refuse to permit access to the property the city administrator, with consent by the mayor or city council use the assistance of the city attorney, to obtain the necessary court order to obtain access. 
(c)  If the city administrator finds any violation of this Code at the premises of any person, the city administrator shall notify the owner, occupant, or user of the sanitary sewer system of the city in writing stating the nature of the violation, the time, place, and date of the inspection, and the right of the person to demand a retest as provided for in subsection (d) of this section, and providing for a reasonable time for abatement to be made. In the absence of unusual circumstances, 30 days shall be considered a reasonable time. An extension of the time to abate any violation may be granted by the city administrator upon written request signed by the owner, occupant, or user of said sanitary sewer system, acknowledging a violation of section 74-194 and promising to abate within a reasonable time. 
(d)  The owner, occupant, or user of said sanitary sewer system shall, upon request, have an absolute right to a retest in the event a violation is discovered. In order to obtain a retest, it shall be necessary that the owner, occupant, or user notify the city administrator, in writing, of the demand for a retest within ten days of the receipt of the notice from the city administrator of a violation. 
(e)  If the owner, occupant, or user of the sanitary sewer system does not abate the violation within the prescribed time limit, or any extension thereof, the following abatement remedies, or any of them, may be resorted to by the city: 
(1)  Abatement by the city for illegal sewer connection. The city may abate the violation, under the direction of the city administrator, and the cost of so doing shall be collected from the person who is responsible for maintaining, allowing, and permitting the violation to exist, with the filing of a lien, filing suit in an appropriate court of competent jurisdiction, suit to collect and may be included in the billing with the city water and sewer services, if water/sewer service is provided the residence. The result of non-payment of utility billing statement which includes the cost for the abatement shall constitute the same means of penalty and collection as described in sections 74-427 through 74-429. 
(2)  Disconnection of sewer service to premises. The city may abate said violation, under the direction of the city administrator, by disconnecting or discontinuing sewer service to the premises found to be in violation, including, but not limited to, the capping of the sanitary sewer serving said premises. 
(3)  Suit to enjoin violation. In addition to the other remedies and penalties provided in this section, the city administrator with council or mayor authorization file appropriate civil actions for a temporary restraining order, temporary injunction, permanent injunction, damages or for contribution, against any person violating this section. 
(4)  Surcharge by city. The city administrator may forward the pertinent information to the city office staff with instructions that the premises are to be surcharged. The surcharge shall be calculated by measuring the perimeter of footage of the dwelling, based upon the outside measurement of the dwelling's foundation. A surcharge of $0.25 per linear foot so calculated plus ten percent of the water usage for each billing period shall be charged. There shall be no maximum charge for such surcharge calculation. The surcharges shall be billed with the regular statements for water and sewer use and shall be due and payable and be deemed to become delinquent at the same time. That surcharge will be discontinued when proof is submitted to the city of a proper disconnection from the sanitary sewer system. 
(f)  Any person aggrieved by any notice of the city administrator under this section may obtain a hearing upon the filing of a written request for such a hearing with the city administrative offices. The request for hearing must be filed with the city administrator within the time allowed for abatement, as provided for in subsection (c) of this section. The written request for a hearing shall contain, at a minimum, the following information: the time, date, and place of the original inspection; the time, date, and place of any retest; the name and address of the person requesting the hearing; the address of the premises subject to the abatement request; and a brief statement of the reasons for requesting a hearing. Any such written request will postpone the date for abatement contained in the original notice to abate until after the hearing has been held. The city administrator shall set the date for the hearing, upon receipt of a written request for such a hearing, as soon as possible, but not more than 15 days after the request is received. 
(1)  The hearing shall be before a board consisting of the city administrator or designee of the maintenance committee, a member of the zoning board of appeals designated by the mayor, and the mayor. The city clerk shall act as the hearing board's secretary and the director of public works shall act as a consultant to the board. The aggrieved person may present any facts or arguments he desires to present, he may be represented by counsel, and he may present such expert testimony or technical evidence as to establish his contentions. Within ten days after the hearing, the board, by a majority vote, may affirm, modify, or reverse any decision of the city administrator. 
(2)  Notice of the board's decision shall be mailed to the aggrieved person within three working days after the rendering of the board's decision. The notice shall be sent by the board to the address of the aggrieved person provided in the request for hearing, and shall contain the following information: a short statement describing the board's decision; the period in which abatement, if any, is required, which shall be at least 15 days but no more than 30 days after said decision is rendered; and a statement describing the aggrieved person's right to appeal to the city council. 
(g)  A person aggrieved by any decision of the hearing board under the provisions of this section may appeal to the city council. The appeal shall be by notice, in writing, addressed to the mayor, stating the reason for the appeal. The notice of appeal must be filed by the person aggrieved within ten days after receipt of the notice of the hearing board's decision. The filing of the notice of appeal shall delay the effective date of the hearing board's order until a decision is rendered in the appeal to the city council. The aggrieved person may present additional facts or arguments as he may desire to the city council. The city council may affirm, modify, or reverse any decision of the hearing board by a vote of a majority of said council in attendance. 
(Code 2008, § 15.04.025; Ord. No. 07-19, 12-3-2007) 
Sec. 42-147. - Nuisance prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person in charge of or in control of any premises within the city, whether as owner, lessee, tenant, occupant or otherwise, to maintain, cause, allow or permit the existence of any nuisance upon the premises. 
Sec. 42-148. - Permitting, occupancy prohibited. 
    It is unlawful to maintain or permit the existence of any dangerous building in the city. It is unlawful for the owner, occupant or person in custody of any dangerous building to permit the same to remain in a dangerous condition, or to occupy such building or permit it to be occupied while it is or remains in a dangerous condition. 
(Code 2008, § 15.04.050; Ord. No. 4-95(part), 1995; Ord. No. 07-19, 12-3-2007) 
Sec. 42-149. - Notice of condemnation. 
    Whenever the chief of police, the fire marshal or the health officer is of the opinion that any building or structure in the city is a dangerous building, he shall file a written statement to this effect with the city clerk. The clerk shall thereupon cause written notice to be served upon the owner thereof, and upon the occupant thereof, if any, by registered mail or by personal service. Such notice shall state that the building has been declared to be in a dangerous condition, and that such dangerous condition must be removed or remedied by repairing or altering the building or by demolishing it; and that the condition must be remedied within 15 days of the date of the notice. Such notice may be in the following terms: 
"To(owner-occupant) of premises of the premises known as (describe building). You are hereby notified that the premises above mentioned has been condemned as a nuisance and a dangerous building after inspection by ____________ . The cause(s) for this decision is/are (insert the facts as to the dangerous decision). You must remedy this condition or demolish the building within 15 days of the date of this notice, or the City will proceed to do so." 
If the person receiving the notice has not compiled therewith or taken an appeal from the determination of the officer or employee finding that a dangerous building exists, within 15 days from the time when this notice is served upon such person by personal service or registered mail, the chief of police may, upon orders of the mayor and city council, proceed to remedy the condition or demolish the dangerous building. 
(Code 2008, § 15.04.060; Ord. No. 4-95(part), 1995; Ord. No. 07-19, 12-3-2007) 
Sec. 42-150. - Notice to abate; abatement procedure. 
    The chief of police is hereby authorized and empowered to notify the person in control of any private property, whether as owner, lessee, tenant, occupant, or otherwise, to remove to an enclosed area on the property or otherwise remove from the property, any junk, trash, debris, abandoned, discarded or unused objects or equipment such as furniture, stoves, refrigerators, freezers, cans or containers which are stored in violation of any section of this article. Said notice shall allow said person ten days to remove said property. Such notice shall be given by certified or registered mail, addressed to the person occupying the premises in question. 
(1)  Abatement procedure. 
a.  Inspection and investigation. When the existence of a public nuisance is brought to the attention of the city administrator, he shall cause an inspection and investigation to be made by the appropriate agencies to determine whether removal is necessary. 
b.  Notice to abate. 
1.  The police chief shall, after inspection and investigation under the provisions of chapter 74, cause a notice in writing to be served upon the person who is responsible for the existence of the nuisance. The notice may be served by mailing a copy thereof to the last known address of the person who is responsible for the existence of the nuisance, return receipt requested. 
2.  The notice shall indicate the date of the inspection and investigation, and the hour and location where the inspection was made. The notice shall set forth what the nuisance consists of and indicate the abatement remedy required. 
(2)  Notification. When any nuisance, or anything likely to become a nuisance, may be found upon any premises, and the person causing such nuisance is unknown or cannot be found, the owner, agent, or occupant of the premises shall be notified by the city administrator or chief of police to abate the same. If owner, agent, or occupant, whose duty it is to abate such nuisance, fails to promptly comply with such notice, abatement remedies, alternatives may be taken. 
(3)  General abatement remedies; alternative. After the expiration of ten days from the date the return receipt requested notice was returned or returned unclaimed to the city, if the nuisance is not abated or other remedy made as required, the city may choose either one of the following abatement remedies: 
a.  Cost of abatement. The nuisance may be abated by the city, under the direction of the city administrator, and the cost of so doing shall be collected from the person who is responsible for the nuisance as stated in subsection (3)b of this section. 
b.  Abatement by the city. The city may abate the violation, under the direction of the city administrator, and the cost of so doing shall be collected from the person who is responsible for maintaining, allowing, and permitting the violation to exist, or owner with the filing of a lien, filing suit in an appropriate court of competent jurisdiction, suit to collect and may be included in the billing with the city water and sewer service statement, if water and or sewer service is provided the residence or property. The result of non-payment of utility billing statement which includes the cost for the abatement shall constitute the same means of penalty and collection as described in sections 74-427 through 74-429. 
(4)  Disconnection of water and or sewer service to premises. The city may abate the nonpayment of said violation, under the direction of the city administrator, by disconnecting or discontinuing water/sewer service to the premises. 
(5)  Suit to enjoin violation. In addition to the other remedies and penalties provided in this section, the city administrator with council or mayor authorization file appropriate civil actions for a temporary restraining order, temporary injunction, permanent injunction, damages or for contribution, against any person violating this section. 
(6)  Abatement in case of emergency. If a nuisance constitutes an emergency, the time for abatement may be reduced by the city administrator in the notice which specifies that the emergency exists. 
(7)  City abatement of weed nuisances and any nuisance as defined in section 42-144. In the event the city chooses to abate a weed or nuisance, the following additional remedies are available to the city: 
a.  Charges. The actual cost incurred by the city for the removal of weeds or any nuisance violation identified in section 42-144; provided, however, if the city uses its own employees to remove the weeds, or any nuisance there is hereby established a charge of $50.00 per hour per employee for the removal of weeds and grasses or any defined nuisance pursuant to this article plus any fees charged for disposal of same. Whether the removal of weeds or the nuisance is accomplished by city employees or not, the charge to the property owner or occupant shall not be less than $100.00, in any event. 
b.  Lien. 
1.  Charges for such grass and weed or nuisance removal shall be a lien upon the premises. Within ten days after such cost and expense is incurred by the city, the city clerk may file a notice of lien with the recorder of deeds of the county. This claim of lien statement shall contain a legal description of the premises, the expenses and costs incurred and the date the weeds, grass were cut, or nuisance removed and a notice that the city claims a lien for this amount. 
2.  Notice of such lien claim shall be mailed to the owner of the premises if his address is known. 
c.  Foreclosure of lien. 
1.  Property subject to a lien for unpaid weed and grass cutting charges or nuisance removal shall be sold for nonpayment of the same and the proceeds of such sale shall be applied to pay the charges after deducting costs, as is the case in the foreclosure of statutory liens. Such foreclosure shall be in equity in the name of the city. 
2.  The city attorney is hereby authorized and directed to institute such proceedings, at the direction of the corporate authorities in the name of the city, in any court having jurisdiction over such matter, against any property for which such bill has remained unpaid for a period of 120 days after the filing of said notice of lien, and for such service a reasonable attorney's fee shall be allowed against the owner of said premises in the foreclosure action. 
(Code 2008, § 15.04.080; Ord. No. 4-95(part), 1995; Ord. No. 07-19, 12-3-2007) 
Sec. 42-151. - Enforcement. 
    Enforcement of this chapter may be accomplished by the city in any manner authorized by law; and, in addition, any person who by reason of another's violation of any provision of this chapter, suffers special damage to himself different from that suffered by other property owners throughout the city generally. The city may bring an action to enjoin or otherwise abate an existing violation. 
(Code 2008, § 15.04.090; Ord. No. 07-19, 12-3-2007) 
Chapter 46 - OFFENSES AND MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 46-1. - Public indecency. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to commit any indecent, lewd or lascivious act in any public place within the city, including, but not limited to, appearing in any public place in a state of nudity or making any indecent exposure of his person. The term "public place," for purposes of this section, means any place where such conduct may reasonably be expected to be viewed by others. 
Sec. 46-2. - Obscenity. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to commit any obscene act within the city. An act is obscene if the average person would find that it appeals to the prurient interest and lacks serious literary, artistic, political or scientific value, and shall include, but is not limited to, the following acts: 
(1)  Selling, delivering, providing, offering or agreeing to sell, deliver or provide any obscene material or other representation; 
(2)  Presenting or directing an obscene play, dance or other performance or participating directly in such performance; 
(3)  Publishing, exhibiting or otherwise making available any obscene material or performance; 
(4)  Creating, buying, procuring or possessing obscene material with intent to disseminate it; or 
(5)  Advertising or otherwise promoting the sale of material represented or held out by him to be obscene, whether or not it is actually obscene. 
(b)  For the purposes of this section: 
(1)  The term "material" means any book, magazine, newspaper, pamphlet, poster, print, picture, figure, image, description, motion picture film, record, recording tape, or videotape. 
(2)  The term "performance" means any motion picture, film, video tape, played record, phonograph or tape, preview, trailer, play, show, skit, dance, or other exhibition performed or presented to or before an audience of one or more, with or without consideration. 
Secs. 46-3-46-22. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - OFFENSES AGAINST PROPERTY 

Sec. 46-23. - Unauthorized placement of advertisements. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to stick, nail, paint, brand, or stamp or in any other manner put upon any house, fence, wall or pavement or other public or private place in this city any written, printed, painted or other advertisement, bill, notice, sign or poster, without having first obtained the consent of the owner or occupant of any such house, fence, wall, pavement or other public or private place. 
(Code 2008, § 9.40.010; Ord. No. 4, div. 5, § 23, 1912) 
Sec. 46-24. - Vandalism; bridges, other public property. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to injure, deface, destroy, or assist in injuring, defacing or destroying any building , fence, sign, tree, tree-box, lamppost, public way, or other property belonging to the city, private business, or person by cutting, breaking, daubing with paint or other substance, driving against, or in any other manner whatsoever. 
(Code 2008, § 9.40.040; Ord. No. 4, div. 6, § 5, 1912) 
Secs. 46-25-46-51. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - OFFENSES AGAINST PUBLIC PEACE AND ORDER 

Sec. 46-52. - Tumultuous, disorderly conduct. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in any violent, tumultuous, offensive or disorderly conduct by: 
(1)  Threatening, traducing, quarreling, challenging to fight or fighting; 
(2)  Using obscene, offensive, profane or unseemly language to the annoyance, disturbance or vexation of another; or 
(3)  Engaging in any conduct likely to provoke a breach of the peace. 
(Code 2008, § 9.24.010; Ord. No. 4, div. 5, § 6, 1912) 
State Law reference- Disorderly conduct, 720 ILCS 5/26-1; municipal authority to prevent disorderly conduct, 65 ILCS 5/1-5-3. 
Sec. 46-53. - Disturbing, lawful assembly. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to willfully interrupt or disturb any lawful assembly, by menace, profanity, vulgar language, or any other disorderly conduct, behavior or discourse within the assembly, or so near to the same as to disturb the good order and peace of the assembly. 
(Code 2008, § 9.24.030; Ord. No. 4, div. 5, § 10, 1912) 
Sec. 46-54. - Endangering pedestrians. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to pursue any amusement or exercise likely to injure or annoy any person passing along the streets or sidewalks which shall collect a crowd of persons so as to interfere with the passage of any vehicle or person upon and along the streets or sidewalks. 
(Code 2008, § 9.24.040; Ord. No. 4, div. 5, § 11, 1912) 
Sec. 46-55. - Throwing stones, missiles. 
    No person shall purposely or heedlessly cast or throw any stone or other missiles from or into any public place, or at any person. 
(Code 2008, § 9.24.050; Ord. No. 4, div. 5, § 12, 1912) 
Sec. 46-56. - Fighting in public place. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly start a fight, or to fight, or to commit any assault or assault and battery anywhere within the city. A person commits an assault when, without lawful authority, engages in conduct which places another in reasonable apprehension of receiving a battery. A person commits a battery when he intentionally or knowingly, without legal justification, and by any means, causes bodily harm to another or makes physical contact of an insulting or provoking nature with another. 
(Code 2008, § 9.24.060; Ord. No. 4, div. 5, § 18, 1912; Ord. No. 13-13, § I, 8-5-2013) 
Sec. 46-57. - Allowing disorderly conduct prohibited. 
    No keeper of any place of amusement, restaurant, or other place of business shall cause or permit any: 
(1)  Loud or boisterous talking; 
(2)  Obscene or profane language; 
(3)  Quarreling, singing, fighting; or 
(4)  Other disturbance likely to breach the peace; 
in or about his place of business, or in any place adjacent thereto subject to his control, to the annoyance or disturbance of another. 
(Code 2008, § 9.24.070; Ord. No. 4, div. 5, § 15, 1912) 
Sec. 46-58. - False alarm. 
    No person shall knowingly make a false alarm of fire, or false cry for assistance when there is no fire. Violations shall be subject to penalty as provided in section 1-8. 
(Code 2008, § 8.04.010; Ord. No. 4, div. 7, § 3, 1912) 
Sec. 46-59. - Explosives, fireworks and weapons. 
(a)  Discharge of weapons or firearms prohibited. The discharge of any weapon or firearm within the city is hereby prohibited except by sworn officers while in the performance of their regular duties and in conformance with established departmental policy, or for the furtherance of the appropriate use of weaponry or weaponry training by authority of the chief of police with approval by the public safety committee of the city. Prior to the discharge of firearms or weaponry for purposes of training while under the authority of the chief of police, there shall be established a safety policy for such use, with approval given by a majority vote of the members of the public safety committee of the city, which such vote shall be included in the minutes record of said committee. 
(b)  Restrictions on the sale, use or explosion of fireworks. Provisions enacted by the legislature of the state for the sale, use and explosion of fireworks as defined by the Pyrotechnic Use Act (425 ILCS 35/1 et seq.), and as amended from time to time, are hereby adopted in their entirety. Strict adherence to the permit application and procedure at 425 ILCS 35/2 et seq. shall be required of all applicants. All permits shall require approval by the chief of police of the city. Any person, firm, co-partnership, or corporation violating the provisions of said act shall receive punishment in accordance with 425 ILCS 35/5. 
(Code 2008, §§ 8.12.010, 8.12.030; Ord. No. 21-03, § 1(part), 2003; Ord. No. 22-03, § 1, 2003) 
Secs. 46-60-46-76. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - MINORS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 46-77-46-95. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - TOBACCO 

Sec. 46-96. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Electronic smoking device means any electronically operated device which causes the user to inhale or exhale any smoke, nicotine, vapor, or other substance other than those produced by unenhanced human expiration of air from the lungs. The term "electronic smoking device" includes any such device, whether manufactured, distributed, marked, or sold as an electronic cigarette, electronic cigar, electronic cigarillo, electronic pipe, electronic hookah, or any other similar device. The term "electronic smoking device" does not include any asthma inhaler or other medical device or product specifically approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration for the use in the mitigation, treatment, or prevention of a medical condition and when such device or product is being used solely for such purpose. 
    Electronic smoking device liquid means a liquid whether packaged in a cartridge containing nicotine or in combination with flavor and chemicals sold or marketed for the refilling of an electronic smoking device. 
(Ord. No. 15-14, § 1, 6-1-2015) 
Sec. 46-97. - Sale of tobacco products. 
    It shall be unlawful to sell, furnish or give away to any minor under the age of 18 years any tobacco product in any form within the city limits, which includes, but is not limited to, electronic smoking device or electronic smoking device liquid. 
(Code 2008, § 9.54.010; Ord. No. 5-01, § 2(part), 2001; Ord. No. 15-14, § 1, 6-1-2015) 
Sec. 46-98. - Possession of tobacco products. 
    It is unlawful for any person under the age of 18 years to possess any tobacco product in any form within the city limits, which includes, but is not limited to, electronic smoking device or electronic smoking device liquid. 
(Code 2008, § 9.54.010; Ord. No. 5-01, § 2(part), 2001; Ord. No. 15-14, § 1, 6-1-2015) 
Secs. 46-99-46-124. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - CURFEW 

Sec. 46-125. - Violation of curfew by minors. 
(a)  It is unlawful for a person less than 17 years of age to be present at or upon any public assembly, building, place, street or highway at the following times: 
(1)  Between 12:01 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. Saturday; 
(2)  Between 12:01 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. Sunday; and 
(3)  Between 11:00 p.m. on Sunday to Thursday, inclusive, and 6:00 a.m. on the following day. 
The following shall not constitute a curfew violation: 
(1)  The minor was accompanied by a parent, legal guardian or other person in custody or control of the minor; 
(2)  The minor was on an errand at the direction of a parent or legal guardian, without any detour or stop; 
(3)  The minor was in a motor vehicle involved in interstate travel; 
(4)  The minor was going to or returning home from an employment activity without any detour or stop; 
(5)  The minor was involved in an emergency; 
(6)  The minor was going to or returning home from, without any detour or stop, an official school, religious, or other recreational activity supervised by adults and sponsored by a government or governmental agency, a civic organization, or another similar entity that takes responsibility for the minor, without any detour or stop; or 
(7)  The minor is married or an emancipated minor under the Emancipation of Minors Act. 
(b)  It is unlawful for a parent, legal guardian, or other person to knowingly permit a person in his custody or control to violate subsection (a) of this section. 
(Code 2008, § 9.60.010; Ord. No. 25-03, § 1(part), 2003) 
Chapter 50 - PARKS AND RECREATION 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 50-1-50-18. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - LAKE EUREKA 

Sec. 50-19. - Hours. 
    The hours during which the lake and park area may be used by the general public shall be from sunrise until 11:00 p.m.; no person or persons shall be permitted to use the lake or park area other than during the aforementioned hours. 
(Code 2008, § 8.16.010; Ord. No. 10-83, § 2, 1983) 
Sec. 50-20. - Fishing-Method. 
    No fishing shall be allowed in Lake Eureka except with a pole and line; not to exceed two poles per person and/or two hooks per line; and it is unlawful to fish with the use of either dead or live minnows for bait. 
(Code 2008, § 8.16.020; Ord. No. 10-83, § 3, 1983; Ord. No. 14-12, § I, 11-17-2014) 
Sec. 50-21. - Fishing-Limit. 
    No person shall be allowed to catch or remove from Lake Eureka more than the number allowed on the posted signs at Lake Eureka. Harvesting of bass is prohibited. No bass may be removed from Lake Eureka. 
(Code 2008, § 8.16.030; Ord. No. 14-04, § I, 5-5-2014) 
Sec. 50-22. - Ice skating. 
    Ice skating is prohibited on Lake Eureka. 
(Code 2008, § 8.16.040; Ord. No. 9-96, 1996; Ord. No. 10-83, § 5, 1983) 
Sec. 50-23. - Snowmobiles; ice boats. 
    It is unlawful for anyone or any person to operate a snowmobile or ice boat on Lake Eureka property. 
(Code 2008, § 8.16.050; Ord. No. 10-83, § 6, 1983) 
Sec. 50-24. - Boats-Construction; permit required. 
    No person shall be allowed to place or use a boat of any type on the lake unless the following conditions have been met: 
(1)  Boat construction must be in a safe or watertight condition, as may be prescribed by the consumer products commission and other regulatory agencies governing consumer products. 
(2)  All state boating regulations as well as this Code shall apply. In the event a conflict may arise, the more restrictive regulations shall prevail. 
(Code 2008, § 8.16.060) 
Sec. 50-25. - Boats-Motor restrictions. 
    A special permit will be allowed to permit watercrafts to launch onto Lake Eureka with a gasoline motor attached to the transom. 
(1)  At no time will gasoline motors be allowed to be started or used for any reason on Lake Eureka. 
(2)  Electric motors will remain the only authorized motor for use on any type of watercraft. 
(3)  Gasoline motor powered watercraft. The administrative offices for the city will provide for sale, special permits for the purpose of allowing watercrafts that have a gasoline motor attached to be launched on Lake Eureka. These permits will be offered for sale to individuals that cannot or choose not to remove the gasoline motor from their watercraft. 
(4)  Non-gasoline powered watercraft. Watercraft without a gasoline motor attached will not be required to purchase a permit and may continue to launch on Eureka Lake at no cost. 
(5)  Permits will be issued through the administration office during regular office hours. 
(6)  Fee for the two-part annual permit for nonresidents will be $40.00 and once paid is non-refundable. The fee for the two-part annual permit for residents will be $20.00 and once paid is non-refundable. The fee for a day permit will be $10.00. 
(7)  Replacement permits may be issued at the discretion of the administrative office for a fee of $15.00 and must contain the same information as the original permit issued. 
(8)  This shall be a two-part permit created by the administrative office and will contain the following information: 
a.  Hull identification number issued from the IDNR; 
b.  Permit requesters name and address; 
c.  Valid permit dates; 
d.  Authorized city signature. 
(9)  Display. One permit is to be displayed in visual manner on the dash of the tow vehicle. The second permit must be kept on the permitted watercraft. 
(10)  Permits must be shown to any authorized city personnel or police officer upon request. 
(11)  A copy of all permits issued will be kept on file at the administrative offices. 
(12)  Eureka High School bass fishing team. The Eureka High School bass fishing team will be allowed to launch watercrafts with gasoline motors for the purpose of practicing and for the purpose of competition at no cost. A special permit will be issued to identify these watercrafts. 
(13)  Any watercraft gasoline engine permit issued by the city can be revoked at any time for any violation of the watercraft code. 
(14)  Exceptions. The following are exempt from this section: city officials or employees acting in an official capacity; Eureka/Goodfield Fire Protection District members for training or emergency purposes; state department of conservation employees acting in an official capacity; or other individuals granted permission by the city council for maintenance of Lake Eureka. Approval must be granted by the administrative offices of the city prior to the starting or use of the gasoline motor on Lake Eureka except in an emergency. 
(Code 2008, § 8.16.070; Ord. No. 10-03, 3-1-2010; Ord. No. 12-07, § I, 5-7-2012; Ord. No. 13-07, § I, 5-6-2013) 
Sec. 50-26. - Boats-Hours permitted. 
    Boating is permitted on the lake from sunrise to sunset only. 
(Code 2008, § 8.16.080; Ord. No. 10-83, § 9, 1983) 
Sec. 50-27. - Operation of watercraft near dam. 
    It is unlawful for any watercraft to be used or operated closer than feet 100 from the concrete spillway or closer than 50 feet of any device used for the maintenance of the lake. 
(Code 2008, § 8.16.090; Ord. No. 10-83, § 10, 1983) 
Sec. 50-28. - Watercraft prohibited overnight. 
    It is unlawful to allow any boat or other watercraft to remain overnight on the lake or on lake property. 
(Code 2008, § 8.16.100; Ord. No. 10-83, § 11, 1983) 
Sec. 50-29. - Boat launching area. 
    There will be one boat launching area with a paved ramp. It is unlawful to unload boats from trailers at any location other than the launching area. Canoes are an exception to this rule and may be launched anywhere on the lake. No trailers for hauling watercraft will be allowed to remain on lake property overnight. 
(Code 2008, § 8.16.110; Ord. No. 10-83, § 12, 1983) 
Sec. 50-30. - Swimming prohibited. 
    It is unlawful for any person to swim in any portion of the lake except for events approved by the city council. 
(Code 2008, § 8.16.120; Ord. No. 13-08, § I, 5-6-2013) 
Sec. 50-31. - Motor vehicle speed limit. 
    It is unlawful to operate or drive any motor vehicle or other type of vehicle in the park area at a speed greater than ten miles per hour. 
(Code 2008, § 8.16.130; Ord. No. 07-06, 6-4-2007) 
Sec. 50-32. - Feeding water fowl. 
    It is unlawful for any person to feed water fowl on Lake Eureka property at any time. 
(Code 2008, § 8.16.140; Ord. No. 10-83, § 15, 1983; Ord. No. 10-01, § I, 1-18-2010) 
Sec. 50-33. - Horses. 
    It is unlawful to have horses on Lake Eureka property except by permission of the city and then only during parades and other city functions. 
(Code 2008, § 8.16.150; Ord. No. 10-83, § 16, 1983) 
Sec. 50-34. - Motor vehicle location restriction. 
    No motorcycles, automobiles, trucks, or vehicles of any type are permitted on Lake Eureka property except on the paved or gravel roads. The only exception to this rule is during city council approved special occasions. 
(Code 2008, § 8.16.160; Ord. No. 10-83, § 17, 1983) 
Sec. 50-35. - Alcoholic beverages prohibited. 
    No alcoholic beverages shall be permitted at any time within Lake Eureka property with the exception for the festival organizing board of the Eureka Reagan Festival an annual event shall be allowed to have a beer tent. 
(Code 2008, § 8.16.170; Ord. No. 10-10, § I, 8-16-2010) 
Sec. 50-36. - Disorderly conduct prohibited. 
    It is unlawful for any person to conduct oneself as to cause a breach of the peace on Lake Eureka property. The causing or making of any unnecessary loud noise that is likely to disturb the public shall be considered disorderly conduct, as well. 
(Code 2008, § 8.16.180; Ord. No. 10-83, § 20, 1983) 
Sec. 50-37. - Garbage control. 
    No garbage, refuse, paper, or litter of any kind shall be left on the ground or thrown or left in the lake or so placed that it could be blown about or scattered by the wind anywhere on Lake Eureka property. 
(Code 2008, § 8.16.190; Ord. No. 10-83, § 21, 1983) 
Sec. 50-38. - Fires. 
    It is unlawful for any person to start a fire on Lake Eureka property unless such fire is contained in a receptacle designed for that purpose. 
(Code 2008, § 8.16.200; Ord. No. 10-83, § 22, 1983) 
Sec. 50-39. - Exceptions. 
    All emergency watercraft and watercraft being used for the maintenance of Lake Eureka are exempt from all provisions of this article, including, but not limited to, hours of operation and the use of gasoline engines. 
(Code 2008, § 8.16.210; Ord. No. 10-83, § 24, 1983) 
Sec. 50-40. - Park fee schedule. 
(a)  Main pavilion rental: $30.00 per day for residents, $50.00 per day for a nonresident. A $50.00 refundable deposit is required prior to picking up the key. The deposit will be returned if the pavilion is left clean and everything is returned to its original condition. 
(b)  Softball summer league fee: $125.00 per team per league, per season. As an example: an eight-team league, $1,000.00. 
(c)  Softball fall league fee: team league play beginning August will be $75.00 per team per league. Figured the same as in subsection (b) of this section. 
(d)  Softball tournaments: $50.00 per day for use of the ball diamonds and lights. 
(e)  Special events: $50.00 per day for special events will be charged if the city personnel are needed to empty trash and check restrooms during the event. If the city personnel did not have to clean and replenish the restrooms or empty trash the $50.00 fee will be returned. 
(f)  Diamond light rental: $15.00 per hour. 
(g)  Diamond rental: a fee of $10.00 per hour will be charged for reserving a diamond if without lights. 
(Code 2008, § 8.16.215) 
Chapter 54 - SOLID WASTE 

Sec. 54-1. - Refuse accumulations restricted; permit required. 
    No person, firm, association, or corporation shall discharge, deposit, place, or permit the discharging, depositing, or placing on any premises within the city limits any garbage, filth, offal, or refuse accumulation of animal, fruit, or vegetable matter, or any other nauseous matter substance of organic or inorganic nature, or waste from sewage disposal facilities, which by reason of its properties, quantity, or decomposition would become foul, odorous, subject to spontaneous combustion, or tend to breed rodents, flies, mosquitoes, or harmful bacteria, or otherwise become detrimental to public health or conducive to the spread of disease, or create, or tend to create a nuisance, except in accordance with a permit first having been obtained from the city. 
(Code 2008, § 8.32.010; Ord. No. 6-76, § 1, 1976; Ord. No. 16-07, § 1, 7-5-2016) 
Sec. 54-2. - When containers should be placed for scheduled pick up. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to place waste in front of any premises, or the front line extended of said premises, even though in a proper container, sooner than 24 hours prior to or later than 24 hours after the scheduled pick-up time by a waste disposal firm. 
(Code 2008, § 8.32.011; Ord. No. 16-07, § 1, 7-5-2016) 
Sec. 54-3. - Permit; application; expiration. 
(a)  Applications for permits shall be in writing and in such form as shall be prescribed by the city. The permit, when issued, shall be signed by the city administrator. 
(b)  Permits shall be issued for the period of the time stated therein, and shall expire at the time stated. 
(Code 2008, § 8.32.020; Ord. No. 6-76, §§ 2, 3, 1976; Ord. No. 16-07, § 1, 7-5-2016) 
Sec. 54-4. - Transportation of refuse; vehicle requirements. 
    No person owning or controlling any vehicle used for the purpose of carrying, transporting, hauling or otherwise moving any substance named in section 54-1, or ashes, refuse or waste, shall cause, suffer, allow or permit any such vehicle to be so loaded, to be in such defective condition, so out of repair, of such faulty construction, or so improperly driven, managed, or controlled that any of the contents thereof shall drop or fall upon any public way or any other public place. Such vehicle shall be so constructed, covered, managed, and controlled as to prevent any part of the contents thereof from falling, leaking or spilling there from. 
(Code 2008, § 8.32.030; Ord. No. 6-76, § 4, 1976; Ord. No. 16-07, § 1, 7-5-2016) 
Sec. 54-5. - Violation; complaint procedure; action by city. 
    Whenever a violation of this chapter occurs, or is alleged to have occurred, any person may file a written complaint with the city. Such complaint shall state fully the causes and basis thereof. The city administrator shall record the complaint, investigate and take such further action as is appropriate. 
(Code 2008, § 8.32.040; Ord. No. 6-76, § 6, 1976; Ord. No. 16-07, § 1, 7-5-2016) 
Chapter 58 - STORMWATER 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 58-1-58-18. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - STORMWATER CONTROL 

Sec. 58-19. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this article, definitions for terms shall be the same as given in section 66-3. 
(Code 2008, § 20.010; Ord. No. 14-10, § I, 10-6-2014) 
Sec. 58-20. - Applicability. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall apply to: 
(1)  Any country estates residential subdivision involving four acres or more of property.
