Sec. 70-199. - Signals. 
    At intersections where traffic is directed by a police officer or by a stop-and-go signal, it is unlawful for any pedestrian to cross the roadway other than with released traffic, if such crossing interferes with the lawful movement of traffic. 
(Code 2008, § 10.40.030; Ord. No. 204, § 10, 1941) 
Secs. 70-200-70-221. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - SKATEBOARDS, ROLLER SKATES AND ROLLER BLADES 

Sec. 70-222. - Skateboard prohibited uses. 
    It is unlawful for any person to operate or ride on a skateboard: 
(1)  On the following streets in the city: 
a.  Illinois Route 117; 
b.  U.S. Route 24; 
c.  Lake Road; 
d.  South Darst Street from East Center Street to Leo Street; 
e.  Reagan Drive; 
f.  100 block of North Meek Street. 
(2)  On any street, sidewalk or public area within the area bounded by Mill Street, Major Street, Cruger Avenue and Liberty Street. 
(3)  On any public or private property where signs have been posted at the entrance or displayed prominently on the property prohibiting the use of either skateboards, roller skates, scooters, or roller blades. 
(4)  On any public or private property when given previous notice, either verbal or written, by a police officer or any owner, manager, or employee of the property. 
(5)  On any parking lots owned or leased by the city. 
(6)  On any place in the city in such a way as to be dangerous to persons or property. 
(7)  In such a manner as to obstruct or slow vehicle or pedestrian traffic on streets or sidewalks. 
(8)  Between sunset and sunrise. 
(Code 2008, § 10.46.010) 
Sec. 70-223. - Roller skates, scooters, and roller blades prohibited uses. 
    It is unlawful for any person to operate or ride on roller skates, roller blades, and scooters: 
(1)  On any of the following streets: 
a.  Illinois Route 117; 
b.  U.S. Route 24; 
c.  Lake Road; 
d.  Reagan Drive. 
(2)  On the following sidewalks in the city: 
a.  Main Street from Mill Street to Cruger Avenue; 
b.  Center Street from Major Street to Liberty Street. 
(3)  On any public or private property where signs have been posted at the entrance or displayed prominently on the property prohibiting the use of either skateboards, roller blades, roller skates, or scooters. 
(4)  On any public or private property when given previous notice, either verbal or written, by a police officer or any owner, manager, or employee of the property. 
(5)  On any parking lots owned or leased by the city. 
(6)  On any place in the city in such a way as to be dangerous to persons or property. 
(7)  In such a way as to obstruct or slow vehicle or pedestrian traffic on streets or sidewalks. 
(Code 2008, § 10.46.020) 
Sec. 70-224. - Certain self-propelled vehicles and machines prohibited uses. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate or ride any machine that can be self-propelled by either a gas or electric motor that cannot be licensed by the state for operation on streets: 
(1)  On any street in the city. 
(2)  On the following sidewalks in the city: 
a.  Main Street from Mill Street to Cruger Avenue; 
b.  Center Street from Major Street to Liberty Street. 
(b)  Exemptions. The following vehicles and machines are exempt from this section: 
(1)  Motorized wheelchairs. 
(2)  Motorized carts (not golf carts) when used by subjects for medical reasons. 
(3)  Vehicles of husbandry. 
(4)  Construction (road or building) vehicles. 
(5)  Machines used for snow removal or lawn care if vehicle is being transported between properties for this purpose. 
(6)  Any vehicle owned by the city if the vehicle is being used in an official capacity. 
(c)  None of these machines or vehicles shall be operated in such a manner as to obstruct or slow vehicle or pedestrian traffic on streets or sidewalks. 
(Code 2008, § 10.46.030) 
Sec. 70-225. - Skateboards, roller skates and roller blades permitted use. 
(a)  It shall be lawful for any person to operate or ride on skateboards, roller skates and roller blades on the following paths and sidewalks within the city: 
(1)  From the Sunny Lane park entrance to the paved trail at the walking bridge, across the paved parking and driving area in the lower park to the skateboard park. 
(2)  From the Lake Road and Route 117 intersection sidewalk across the pedestrian bridge, along the sidewalk to the paved road and then north to the skateboard park. 
(3)  Access use only to and from the skate board park on the paved trail running east/west along Lake Road to the lower park paved road to the skateboard park. 
(b)  All other paved or nature trails, roads and parking areas within the park grounds shall be prohibited from use by persons operating or riding on skate boards, roller skates and roller blades. 
(c)  None of the persons operating skateboards, roller skates and roller blades shall be operated in such a manner as to obstruct or slow vehicle or pedestrian traffic on streets or sidewalks. 
(Code 2008, § 10.46.35) 
Chapter 74 - WATER AND SEWER 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 74-1. - Sewer system. 
    Anyone owning property not within the annexed territory of the city and on whose property has been officially declared to exist in a health hazard area shall be given the opportunity to hook onto the city sewer system. The property owner shall incur their proportionate share of all capital costs to include engineering, administrative, bond acquisition (funding), legal and construction costs. The property owner shall pay their fair share through a debt service charge computed to amortize the indebtedness of a special taxing district composed of property owner. This charge shall be in addition to the same user charge paid by the people within the city limits. 
(Code 2008, § 13.02.010; Ord. No. 8-78; Ord. of 7-23-1981(part)) 
Sec. 74-2. - Water system. 
    Anyone owning property not within the annexed territory of the city shall be given an opportunity to hook on to the city water system. The property owner shall incur their proportionate share of all capital costs to include engineering, administrative, bond acquisition (funding), legal and construction costs. The type, size and spacing of water mains, valves and fire hydrants shall be specified by the city engineers and the capital costs of the pipe, valves and fire hydrants shall also be incurred by the property owner. 
(Code 2008, § 13.02.020; Ord. of 7-23-1981(part)) 
Sec. 74-3. - Extensions subject to availability. 
    Any water or sewer extensions to areas outside the city limits shall be subject to availability of pipeline and treatment plant capacity to handle flows from such areas and shall be subject to all permitting and other requirements of the state and city. 
(Code 2008, § 13.02.030; Ord. of 7-23-1981(part)) 
Sec. 74-4. - Negotiation for deviations. 
    Deviation to the above conditions and restrictions may be negotiated by the property owner(s) when and if a petition for annexation is presented for the consideration of the city planning commission and the specific conditions and/or waivers are made a part of the annexation agreement. 
(Code 2008, § 13.02.040; Ord. of 7-23-1981(part)) 
Secs. 74-5-74-26. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - REGULATIONS FOR SEWER SERVICE 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 74-27. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article and in article V of this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Administrator means the administrator of the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency. 
    Basic user charge means the basic assessment levied on all users of the public sewer system. 
    BOD (denoting biochemical oxygen demand) means the quantity of oxygen utilized in the biochemical oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory procedure in five days at 20 degrees Centigrade, expressed in milligrams per liter. 
    Building drain means that part of the lowest piping of a drainage system which receives the discharge from soil, waste and other drainage pipes inside the walls of the building and conveys it to the building sewer or other approved point of discharge, beginning five feet (1.5 meters) outside the inner face of the building wall. 
    Building sewer means the extension from the building drain to the public sewer or other place of disposal. 
    Capital improvement charge means a charge levied on users to improve extend or reconstruct the sewage treatment works. 
    Combined sewer means a sewer which is designed and intended to receive wastewater, stormwater, surface water and groundwater drainage. 
    Commercial user means and includes transit lodging, retail and wholesale establishments or places engaged in selling merchandise or rendering services. 
    Control manhole means a structure located on a site from which industrial wastes are discharged. Where feasible, the manhole shall have an interior drop. The purpose of a control manhole is to provide access for the city representative to sample and/or measure discharges. 
    Debt service charge means the amount to be paid each billing period for payment of interest, principal and coverage of (loan, bond, etc.) outstanding. 
    Director means the director of the state environmental protection agency. 
    Easement means an acquired legal right for the specific use of land owned by others. 
    Effluent criteria are defined in any applicable NPDES permit. 
    Federal Act means the Federal Clean Water Act (33 USC 466 et seq.) as amended (Pub. L. 95-217). 
    Federal Grant II means the U.S. government participation in the financing of the construction of treatment works as provided for by Title II-Grants for Construction of Treatment Works of the Act and implementing regulations. 
    Floatable oil means oil, fat or grease in a physical state such that it will separate by gravity from wastewater by treatment in an approved pretreatment facility. A wastewater shall be considered free of floatable fat if it is properly pretreated and the wastewater does not interfere with the collection system. 
    Garbage means solid wastes from the domestic and commercial preparation, cooking, and dispensing of food, and from the handling, storage and sale of food. 
    Industrial users means and includes establishments engaged in manufacturing activities involving the mechanical or chemical transformation of materials of substance into products. 
    Industrial waste means any solid, liquid or gaseous substance discharged, permitted to flow or escaping from any industrial, manufacturing, commercial or business establishment or process or from the development, recovery or processing of any natural resource as distinct from sanitary sewage. 
    Institutional/governmental user means and includes schools, churches, penal institutions, and users associated with federal, state, and local governments. 
    Local capital cost charge means charges for costs other than the operation, maintenance and replacement costs, i.e. debt service and capital improvement costs. 
    Major contributing industry means an industrial user of the publicly owned treatment works that: 
(1)  Has a low of 50,000 gallons or more per average work day; 
(2)  Has a flow greater than the ten percent of the flow carried by the municipal system receiving the waste; 
(3)  Has in its waste, a toxic pollutant in toxic amounts as defined in standards issued under section 307(a) of the Federal Act; or 
(4)  Is found by the permit issuance authority, in connection with the issuance of the NPDES permit to the publicly owned treatment works receiving the waste, to have significant impact, either singly or in combination with other contributing industries, on that treatment works or upon the quality of effluent from that treatment works. 
    Milligrams per liter means a unit of the concentration of water or wastewater constituent. It is 0.001g of the constituent in 1,000ml of water. It has replaced the unit formerly used commonly, parts per million, to which it is approximately equivalent, in reporting the results of water and wastewater analysis. 
    Natural outlet means any outlet into a watercourse, pond, ditch, lake, or other body of surface water or groundwater. 
    NPDES permit means any permit or equivalent document or requirements issued by the administrator, or where appropriated by the director, after enactment of the federal Clean Water Act to regulate the discharge of pollutants pursuant to section 402 of the Federal Act. 
    Person means any and all persons, natural or artificial including any individual, firm, company, municipal or private corporation, association, society, institution enterprise, governmental agency or other entity. 
    pH means the logarithm (base 10) of the reciprocal of the hydrogen-ion concentration expressed by one of the procedures outlined in the IEPA Division of Laboratories Manual of Laboratory Methods. 
    Population equivalent is a term used to evaluate the impact of industrial or other waste on a treatment works or stream. One population equivalent is 100 gallons of sewage per day, containing 0.17 pounds of BOD and 0.20 pounds of suspended solids. 
    ppm means parts per million by weight. 
    Pretreatment means the treatment of wastewaters from sources before introduction into the wastewater treatment works. 
    Properly shredded garbage means the wastes from the preparation, cooking and dispensing of food that have been shredded to such a degree that all particles will be carried freely under the flow conditions normally prevailing in public sewers, with no particle greater than one-half inch (1.27 centimeters) in any dimension. 
    Public sewer means a sewer provided by or subject to the jurisdiction of the city. It also includes sewers within or outside the city boundaries that serve one or more persons and ultimately discharge into the city sanitary sewer system, even though those sewers may not have been constructed with city funds. 
    Replacement means expenditures for obtaining and installing equipment, accessories or appurtenances which are necessary during the useful life of the treatment works to maintain the capacity and performance for which such works were designed and constructed. The term "operation and maintenance" includes replacement. 
    Residential user means all dwelling units such as houses, mobile homes, apartments, permanent multifamily dwellings. 
    Sanitary sewer means a sewer that conveys sewage or industrial wastes or a combination of both, and into which stormwaters, surface waters and groundwaters or polluted industrial wastes are not intentionally admitted. 
    Sewage is used interchangeably with "wastewater." 
    Sewer means a pipe or conduit for conveying sewage or any other waste liquids, including stormwater, and groundwater drainage. 
    Sewerage means the system of sewers and appurtenances for the collection, transportation and pumping of sewage. 
    Sewerage fund means the principal accounting designation for all revenues received in the operation of the sewerage system. 
    Slug means any discharge of water, sewage or industrial waste which in concentration of any given constituent or in quantity of low exceeds for any period of duration longer than 15 minutes more than five times the average 24-hour concentration or flows during normal operation. 
    State Act means the Illinois Anti-Pollution Bond Act of 1970. 
    State grant means the state participation in the financing of the construction of treatment works as provided for by the Illinois Anti-Pollution Bond Act and for making such grants as filed with the Secretary of State of the State of Illinois. 
    Storm sewer means a sewer that carries stormwater, surface water and groundwater drainage but excludes sewage and industrial wastes other than unpolluted cooling water. 
    Stormwater runoff means that portion of the precipitation that is drained into the sewers. 
    Surcharge means the assessment in addition to the basic user charge and debt service charge which is levied on those persons whose wastes are greater in strength than the concentration values established in this chapter. 
    Suspended solids (SS) means solids that either float on the surface of, or are in suspension in water, sewage or industrial waste, and which are removable by a laboratory filtration device. Quantitative determination of suspended solids shall be made in accordance with procedures set forth in the IEPA Division of Laboratories Manual of Laboratory Methods. 
    Unpolluted water means water quality equal to or better than the effluent criteria in effect or water that would not cause violation of receiving water quality standards and would not be benefited by discharge to the sanitary sewers and wastewater treatment facilities provided. 
    Useful life means the estimated period during which the collection system and/or treatment works will be operated. 
    User charge means a charge levied on users of treatment works for the cost of operation, maintenance and replacement. 
    User class means the type of user residential institutional/governmental, commercial, or industrial as defined in this section. 
    Wastewater means the spent water of a community. From this standpoint of course, it may be a combination of the liquid and water carried wastes from residences, commercial buildings, industrial plants and institutions, together with any groundwater, surface water, and stormwater that may be present. 
    Wastewater facilities means the structures, equipment and processes required to collect carry away and treat domestic and industrial wastes and transport effluent to a watercourse. 
    Wastewater service charge means the charge per quarter or month levied on all users of the wastewater facilities. The service charge shall be computed as outlined in this article, and shall consist of the total or the basic user charge, the local capital cost and a surcharge, if applicable. 
    Wastewater treatment works means an arrangement of devices and structures for treating wastewater, industrial wastes and sludge. The term "wastewater treatment works" is sometimes used as synonymous with "waste treatment plant" or "wastewater treatment plant" or "pollution control plant." 
    Water quality standards are defined in the water pollution regulations of the state. 
    Watercourse means a channel in which a flow of water occurs, either continuously or intermittently. 
(Code 2008, § 13.04.010; Ord. No. 11-83(part), 1983) 
Sec. 74-28. - Unsanitary deposit of garbage and wastes unlawful. 
    It is unlawful for any person to place, deposit or permit to be deposited in any unsanitary manner on public or private property within the city or in any area under the jurisdiction of the city, any human or animal excrement, garbage or other objectionable waste. 
(Code 2008, § 13.04.020; Ord. No. 11-83(part), 1983) 
Sec. 74-29. - Unlawful discharges into natural outlet unlawful. 
    It is unlawful to discharge to any natural outlet within the city or in any area under the jurisdiction of the city, any sewage or other polluted waters, except where suitable treatment has been provided in accordance with subsequent provisions of the ordinance codified herein. 
(Code 2008, § 13.04.030; Ord. No. 11-83(part), 1983) 
Sec. 74-30. - Discharging polluting substances into storm sewer drainage system unlawful. 
    It is unlawful for any person, firm, or corporation to connect or cause to be connected any drain carrying or to carry any toilet, sink, basement, septic tank, cesspool, or industrial waste, or any other fixture or device discharging any form of polluting substance to the storm sewer drainage system in the city, including stormwater drains or combination stormwater drains along and near U.S. Highway No. 24. 
(Code 2008, §§ 13.04.060, 13.04.070; Ord. No. 273, §§ 1, 2, 1955; Ord. No. 3-60, §§ 1, 2, 1960) 
Sec. 74-31. - Discharges; compliance with state and federal standards. 
    All disposal by any person into the sewer system is unlawful except those discharges in compliance with federal standards promulgated pursuant to the Federal Act and more stringent state and local standards. 
(Code 2008, § 13.04.096; Ord. No. 11-83(part), 1983) 
Sec. 74-32. - Privies, septic tanks, cesspools. 
    Except as hereinafter provided, it is unlawful to construct or maintain any privy, privy vault, septic tank, cesspool, or other facility intended or used for the disposal of sewage. 
(Code 2008, § 13.04.040; Ord. No. 11-83(part), 1983) 
Sec. 74-33. - Tampering with or destruction of public sewage works equipment prohibited. 
    No unauthorized person shall maliciously, willfully or negligently break, damage, destroy or tamper with any structure, appurtenance or equipment which is a part of the sewage works. 
(Code 2008, § 13.04.260; Ord. No. 11-83(part), 1983) 
Sec. 74-34. - Powers and authority of inspectors. 
    The director of public works and other duly authorized employees of the city, the state environmental protection agency, bearing proper credentials and identification shall be permitted to enter all properties for the purposes of inspection, observation, measurement, sampling and testing in accordance with the provisions of the ordinance codified herein. The city shall have no authority to inquire into any processes, including metallurgical, chemical, oil refining, ceramic, paper or other industries beyond that point having a direct bearing on the kind and source of discharge to the sewers or waterway or facilities for waste treatment. 
(Code 2008, § 13.04.270; Ord. No. 11-83(part), 1983) 
Sec. 74-35. - Inspectors to observe company safety rules. 
    While performing the necessary work on private properties referred to in section 74-34, the director of public works or a duly authorized employees of the city, the state environmental protection agency, and the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency shall observe all safety rules applicable to the premises established by the company and the company shall be held harmless for injury or death to the city employees and the city shall indemnify the company against liability claims and demands for personal injury or property damage asserted against the company and growing out of the gauging and sampling operating, except as such may be caused by negligence or failure of the company to maintain conditions as required in section 74-202. 
(Code 2008, § 13.04.280; Ord. No. 11-83(part), 1983) 
Sec. 74-36. - Inspectors entrance onto easements. 
    The duly authorized employees of the city bearing proper credentials and identification shall be permitted to enter all private properties through which the city holds a duly negotiated easement for the purpose of, but not limited to, inspection, observation, measurement, sampling, repair and maintenance of any portion of the sewage works lying within the easement. All entry and subsequent work, if any, on the easement, shall be done in full accordance with the terms of the duly negotiated easement pertaining to the private property involved. 
(Code 2008, § 13.04.290; Ord. No. 11-83(part), 1983) 
Sec. 74-37. - Violation-Notification; permit revocation. 
    Any person found to be violating any provision of the ordinance codified herein except section 74-33 shall be served by the city with written notice stating the nature of the violation and providing a reasonable time limit for the satisfactory correction thereof. The offender shall, within the period of time stated in such notice, permanently cease all violations. The city may revoke any permit for sewage disposal as a result of any violation of any provision of the ordinance codified herein. 
(Code 2008, § 13.04.300; Ord. No. 11-83(part), 1983) 
Sec. 74-38. - Violation-Liability to the city. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of the ordinance codified herein shall become liable to the city by reasons of such violation. 
(Code 2008, § 13.04.320; Ord. No. 11-83(part), 1983) 
Secs. 74-39-74-64. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CONNECTIONS 

Sec. 74-65. - Toilet facilities; installation, connection to public sewers. 
    The owner of all the houses, buildings, or properties used for human occupancy, employment, recreation, or other purposes situated within the city and abutting on any street, alley or right-of-way in which there is not located or may in the future be located any public sanitary (or combined) sewer of the city, is hereby required at his expense to install suitable toilet facilities therein, and to connect such facilities directly with the proper public sewer in accordance with the provisions of this chapter, within 90 days after date of official notice to do so, provided that the public sewer is within 300 feet of the property line. 
(Code 2008, § 13.04.050; Ord. No. 11-83(part), 1983) 
Sec. 74-66. - Exemption from connection through agreement with the city. 
    A request for exemption from connection to the public sewer may be made with the following agreement: 
An individual, corporation and/or an agent acting on behalf of an estate and or property owner may request an exemption from a required connection to a City public sewer if they are within 300 feet of a public sewer and required to connect. The City of Eureka may be allowed by way of Resolution to enter into an agreement with said owner to allow the owner to put in a septic system and not connect to the City Public Sewer using the following Resolutions and conditions set forth. The Eureka City Council reserves the right to modify the resolution of agreement from time to time as they deem necessary. 
An Agreement between the parties duly passed by the Eureka City Council at a regularly scheduled council shall authorize the City of Eureka to enter into an agreement with ____________ owners of the property at ____________ in the City of Eureka, Woodford County, State of Illinois to allow the property to maintain, repair, and or replace a private septic system within 300 feet of a public sewer. 
WHEREAS, ____________ has requested that their property located at ____________ in the City of Eureka Woodford County be allowed to maintain, repair, and or replace a sanitary sewer septic system; and 
WHEREAS, the property is located within 300 feet of a municipal sewer and is required to connect to the public sewer; and 
WHEREAS, the City of Eureka and the Woodford County Health Department has determined that it is in the best interest of the property owners due to cost, grade or other cause deemed reasonable that the property will be allowed to maintain, repair, and or replace the sanitary sewer septic system with the rules and regulations stipulated herein; and 
WHERAS, the owners of record agree to abide by the listed requirements for inspection, testing and submittal of records to the City of Eureka; and 
WHEREAS, the owners agree that if they fail to perform the inspections as required, submit records in a timely manner, or fail any of the minimum standards for discharge they will be required to connect to the City of Eureka public sewer within three months of and notification by the City to the current owner or their successors of their failure to meet the obligations of this agreement and will be subject to the fines imposed in this agreement; and 
WHEREAS, the owners agree to the following testing, record submittal, inspections, fines and collection procedure per this agreement: 
A. Testing and Records. 
1. Each privately owned septic system shall be tested and inspected at the time of installation and at least twice a year or more frequently if requested by the City of Eureka if it is determined the discharge was in excess of ____________ at any time. 
2. All inspections and testing shall be performed by a licensed and certified ____________ . 
3. All cost associated with the testing, inspections, records log and submittal of results to the City of Eureka shall be paid by the property owner. 
4. Property owner shall submit to the City of Eureka the test results and maintenance log no later than January 31 and July 31 of each year. Failure to submit required results by the due dates will result in a fine of $100.00 per day and each day shall constitute an addition violation and fine. The fine will be attached to the property owner's water/sewer monthly utility billing and shall be subject to collection per the Eureka Municipal Code Chapter 74, Water and Sewer. 
5. The City will not be responsible for notification of inspection deadlines and the responsibility for timely inspections and reporting shall be the sole responsibility of the property owner. 
6. A maintenance log shall be maintained by the owner and include: 
a. Date of each test. 
b. Name and of persons performing the test. 
c. Test results; 
d. Repairs or servicing required; 
e. Repairs and date completed; and 
f. Servicing performed and date completed. 
B. The City Superintendent of Streets and Alleys and other duly authorized employees of the City, the Illinois Environmental Protection Agency, bearing proper credentials and identification shall be permitted to enter all properties for the purposes of inspection, observation, measurement, sampling and testing. 
WHEREAS, the owner agrees that the City of Eureka does not bear any responsibility for any cost associated with the maintenance, repair, and or replacement of the private septic system, inspections, maintenance of records. 
WHEREAS, The City of Eureka does not bear any responsibility for any cost associated with any construction cost associated with constructing a sewer main or the connection to the municipal sewer if required to do so, due to failure of the owner to meet the terms of this agreement as approved and agreed to by the property owner of record or requirement by the Environmental Protection Agency of the State of Illinois or any authorized agency having jurisdiction over septic system discharge or contamination by same. 
WHEREAS, Successors and Assigns. This Agreement shall be binding upon and inure to the benefit of the Parties hereto and their respective successors and permitted assigns. 
WHEREAS, Except as otherwise expressly provided herein, this Agreement supersedes all prior agreements, negotiations, and discussions relative to the subject matter hereof and is a full integration of the agreement of the parties. 
WHERAS, If any provision, covenant, or portion of this Agreement, or its application to any person, entity, or property is held invalid, such invalidity shall not affect the application or validity of any other provisions, covenants or portions of this Agreement (and, to that end, any provisions, covenants, agreements or portions of this Agreement are declared to be severable). 
WHEREAS, this agreement will be filed with the Woodford County Recorder with the property tax ID number ____________ shoeing the conditions and requirements of this agreement. 
THERFORE BE IT RESOLVED that (I) (We) as owners of record ____________ has/have read and agree to the terms of this Ordinance of agreement with the City of Eureka including the performance of the inspections as required, submittal of records in a timely manner to the City of Eureka, or if I fail any of the minimum standards for discharge will be subject to immediate connection to the City public sewer. The Agreement will be effective with the date of approval by the Eureka City Council and Mayor in and for the City of Eureka. The signed agreement will be filed and recorded with the attached plat identifying the property subject to the terms and requirements of this agreement and so approved with the owner's signature, Eureka, Illinois, Woodford County, Illinois. 
(Code 2008, § 13.04. 055; Ord. No. 11-05, § I, 4-18-2011) 
Secs. 74-67-74-90. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - PRIVATE SEWAGE DISPOSAL 

Sec. 74-91. - Private sewage disposal; connection. 
    Where a public sanitary sewer is not available under the provisions of section 74-65, the building sewer shall be connected to a private sewage disposal system complying with the provisions of this article. 
(Code 2008, § 13.04.082; Ord. No. 11-83(part), 1983) 
Sec. 74-92. - Permit required; application; fee. 
    Before commencement of construction of a private sewage disposal system the owner shall first obtain a written permit signed by the administrator. The application for such permit shall be made on a form furnished by the city, any plans, specifications and other information as deemed necessary by the administrator. A permit and inspection fee of $400.00 shall be paid to the city at the time the application is filed. 
(Code 2008, § 13.04.084; Ord. No. 11-83(part), 1983) 
Sec. 74-93. - Private sewage disposal-Permit; effectiveness. 
    A permit for a private sewage disposal system shall not become effective until the installation is completed to the satisfaction of the director of public works. He shall be allowed to inspect the work at any stage of construction and, in any event, the applicant for the permit shall notify the city when the work is ready for final inspection, and before any underground portions are covered. The inspection shall be made within 48 hours of the receipt of written notice by the city. 
(Code 2008, § 13.04.085; Ord. No. 11-83(part), 1983) 
Sec. 74-94. - Private sewage disposal-Compliance with state recommendations. 
    The type, capacities, location, and layout of a private sewage disposal system shall comply with all recommendations of the state Private Sewage Disposal Licensing Act and Code and with the state environmental protection agency. No permit shall be issued for any private sewage disposal system employing subsurface soil absorption facilities where the area of the lot is less than 15,000 square feet. No septic tank or cesspool shall be permitted to discharge to any natural outlet. 
(Code 2008, § 13.04.086; Ord. No. 11-83(part), 1983) 
Sec. 74-95. - Private sewage disposal-Connection to public sewer when available. 
    At such time as a public sewer becomes available to a property served by a private sewage disposal system as provided in section 74-65, a direct connection shall be made to the public sewer in compliance with this chapter, and any septic tanks, cesspools, and similar private sewage disposal facilities shall be abandoned and filled with suitable material. 
(Code 2008, § 13.04.088; Ord. No. 11-83(part), 1983) 
Sec. 74-96. - Private sewage disposal-Maintenance; costs. 
    The owner shall operate and maintain the private sewage disposal facilities in a sanitary manner at all times, and at no expense to the city. 
(Code 2008, § 13.04.090; Ord. No. 11-83(part), 1983) 
Sec. 74-97. - Private sewage disposal-Additional requirements. 
    No statement contained in this article shall be construed to interfere with any additional requirements that may be imposed by the health officer. 
(Code 2008, § 13.04.092; Ord. No. 11-83(part), 1983) 
Sec. 74-98. - Private sewage disposal-Public sewer availability. 
    When a public sewer becomes available, the building sewer shall be connected to the sewer within 60 days and the private sewage disposal system shall be cleaned of sludge and filled with clean bank run gravel or dirt. 
(Code 2008, § 13.04.094; Ord. No. 11-83(part), 1983) 
Secs. 74-99-74-124. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - PERMITS 

Sec. 74-125. - Constructions, tapping; permit, license, bond requirements. 
(a)  No unauthorized person shall uncover, make any connections with or opening into, use, alter, or disturb any public sewer or appurtenance thereof without first obtaining a written permit from the city. 
(b)  Any individual or firm who taps the public sewer for the purpose of connecting a private building sewer thereon shall first obtain a permit from the city. 
(c)  Any individual or firm who as a contractor or builder contracts to build or construct a private sewer and to tap the public sewer for the purpose of connecting a private building sewer thereon shall first obtain a license from the city as such contractor, and, before the license is granted, furnish to the city a performance bond in the sum of $2,500.00 indemnifying the city and private property owner against any loss or damage resulting from the work of the license holder. 
(Code 2008, § 13.04.080; Ord. No. 260, § 401, 1952) 
Sec. 74-126. - Building sewers and connections; permit required. 
    No unauthorized person shall uncover, make any connections with, or opening into; use; alter; or disturb any public sewer or appurtenance thereof without first obtaining written permit from the city. 
(Code 2008, § 13.04.095; Ord. No. 11-83(part), 1983) 
Sec. 74-127. - Building sewer permits-Types; applications fees. 
    There shall be two classes of building sewer permits: 
(1)  For residential, wastewater service; and 
(2)  To commercial, institutional/governmental or industrial wastewater service. 
In either case, the owner or his agent shall make application on a special form furnished by the city. The permit application shall be supplemented by any plans, specifications, or other information considered pertinent in the judgment of the city. A permit and inspection fee of $400.00 per residential living unit and for any commercial building. Sewer permits shall be paid to the city at the time the application is filed. The industry, as a condition of permit authorization, must provide information describing its wastewater constituents, characteristics and type of activity. 
(Code 2008, § 13.04.098; Ord. No. 11-83(part), 1983) 
Sec. 74-128. - Building sewer permits-Issuance. 
    A building sewer permit will only be issued and a sewer connection shall only be allowed if it can be demonstrated that the downstream sewerage facilities, including sewers, pump stations and wastewater treatment to sewer backups. 
(Code 2008, § 13.4.100; Ord. No. 11-83(part), 1983) 
Sec. 74-129. - Applications. 
    Applications for private sewage disposal and for residential or commercial sewers are on file in the public works department. 
Secs. 74-130-74-156. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - CONSTRUCTION 

Sec. 74-157. - Building sewer cost and expense. 
    All cost and expense incident to the installation and connection of the building sewer shall be borne by the owner. The owner shall indemnify the city from any loss or damage that may directly or indirectly be occasioned by the installation of the building sewer, included, but not limited to, sewer backups. 
(Code 2008, § 13.4.101) 
Sec. 74-158. - Separate and independent building sewers required. 
    A separate and independent building sewer shall be provided for every building, except that where one building stands at the rear of another on an interior lot and no private sewer is available or can be constructed to the rear building through an adjoining alley; court, yard or driveway, the building sewer from the front building may be extended to the rear building and the whole considered as one building sewer. 
(Code 2008, § 13.4.102; Ord. No. 11-83(part), 1983) 
Sec. 74-159. - Use of old building sewers. 
    Old building sewers may be used in connection with new buildings only when they are found, on examination and test by the city, to meet all requirements of the ordinance codified in this division. 
(Code 2008, § 13.4.103; Ord. No. 11-83(part), 1983) 
Sec. 74-160. - Construction requirements. 
    The size, slope, alignment, materials of construction of a building sewer, and the methods to be used in excavating, placing of the pipe, jointing, testing, and backfilling the trench, shall all conform to the requirements of the building and plumbing code or other applicable rules and regulations of the city. In the absence of code provisions or in amplification thereof, the materials and procedures set forth in appropriate specifications of the American Society of Testing Materials, Water Pollution Control Federation Manual of Practice No.9, and Standard Specifications for Water and Sewer Main Construction in Illinois shall apply. 
(Code 2008, § 13.4.104; Ord. No. 11-83(part), 1983) 
Sec. 74-161. - Elevation of building sewer. 
    When possible, the building sewer shall be brought to the building at an elevation below the basement floor. In all buildings in which any building drain is too low to permit gravity flow to the public sewer, sanitary sewage carried by such building drain shall be lifted by a means which is approved in accordance with section 74-31 and discharged to the building sewer. 
(Code 2008, § 13.4.105; Ord. No. 11-83(part), 1983) 
Sec. 74-162. - Connections to roof downspouts, area way drains, etc. 
    No person(s) shall make connection of roof downspouts, exterior foundation drains, areaway drains, or other sources of surface runoff or groundwater to a building sewer or building drain which in turn is connected directly or indirectly to a public sanitary sewer. 
(Code 2008, § 13.4.106; Ord. No. 11-83(part), 1983) 
Sec. 74-163. - Building sewer-Connection to public sewers. 
    The connection of the building sewer into the public sewer shall conform to the requirements of the state plumbing code. All such connections shall be made gastight and watertight. Any deviation from the prescribed procedures and materials must be approved by the city before installation. 
(Code 2008, § 13.4.107; Ord. No. 11-83(part), 1983) 
Sec. 74-164. - Building sewer-Notification when ready for inspection and connection. 
    The applicant for the building sewer permit shall notify the city when the building sewer is ready for inspection and connection to the public sewer. The connection shall be made under the supervision of the director of public works or his designee. 
(Code 2008, § 13.4.108; Ord. No. 11-83(part), 1983) 
Sec. 74-165. - Excavations to be guarded with barricades. 
    All excavations for building sewer installation shall be adequately guarded with barricades and lights so as to protect the public from hazard. Streets, sidewalks, parkways, and other public property disturbed in the course of the work shall be restored in a manner satisfactory to the city. 
(Code 2008, § 13.4.109; Ord. No. 11-83(part), 1983) 
Sec. 74-166. - Construction materials-Sanitary sewer pipe. 
(a)  Specifications and standards for sanitary sewer pipe in the city sewer and water systems are as provided in this section. 
(b)  The sanitary sewer shall be extra strength and standard strength clay pipe, ASTM Designation C-700 with the following modifications: 
(1)  Vitrified clay sewer pipe joints shall conform to ASTM C-425. Plain end vitrified clay sewer pipe shall be jointed with PVC bell material conforming to ASTM C-1784 and flexible gasket meeting ASTM C-425 specifications. 
(2)  Polyvinyl chloride (PVC) sewer pipe joints shall conform to ASTM D-3034, Type PSM for sizes four inches to 15.1 inches and ASTM F-679 for sizes 18 inches to 27 inches. Standard dimensions ratio (SDR) shall be specified in the special provisions. Minimum acceptable SDR shall be 26. Polyvinyl chloride (PVC) sewer pipe joints shall be solvent welded joints per ASTM D-2855 or flexible electrometric seals per ASTM D-3212. 
(3)  Any sewer pipe or sewer pipe material not conforming to the above specifications shall not be used without prior permission from the city administrator of the city. 
(4)  All material and construction shall conform to the current edition of the "Standard Specifications for Water and Sewer Main Construction in Illinois." 
(Code 2008, § 13.4.110) 
Sec. 74-167. - Construction materials-Large size concrete sewer pipe. 
    Large size concrete sewer pipe shall meet the following standards and specifications: ASTM Designation C14, with the following modifications: 
(1)  Sewer pipe shall be subject to rejection because of: 
a.  Variations in any dimensions exceeding 50 percent of the permissible given in Table 1 of the designated; 
b.  Insecure attachments of branches on spurs; 
c.  Pipe lengths less than three feet; four feet or more is preferable. 
(2)  Crushing strength requirements by the three-edge bearing method of testing, as given in Table 1, shall be considered as minimum requirements. 
(3)  Maximum absorption shall not exceed six percent. 
(Code 2008, § 13.04.112; Ord. No. 10-79, § 3, 1979) 
Sec. 74-168. - Construction materials-Cast iron pipe centrifugally cast in metal molds for water or other liquids. 
    The following standards and specifications shall apply to cast iron pipe centrifugally cast in metal molds, for water or other liquids: ANSI 21.6, Class 150, and Cast Iron Pipe Centrifugally Cast in Sand Lined Molds, for Water or Other Liquids, ANSI 21.8, Class 150. 
(1)  Joints for cast iron pipe. Mechanical type or slip-on type as specified under Pipe, Cast Iron Pressure, Federal Specification WW-P-421b, Types 11 and Ill, joint assembly. Joints to be installed according to manufacturer's instructions; 
(2)  Corrugated metal pipe. Article in "Illinois Standard Highway Specifications," entitled Corrugated Metal Pipe. 
(Code 2008, § 13.04.114; Ord. No. 10-79, § 4, 1979) 
Sec. 74-169. - Construction materials-PVC plastic pipe, couplings and fittings. 
    The following standards and specifications shall apply to PVC plastic pipe, couplings and fittings to be used on all public properties and easements: Rigid PVC pressure pipe as described in this specification is designed to carry water at pressures up to the maximum class rating. Piping system shall be Certain-Teed Fluid-Tite, Johns-Manville PVC, or equal. 
(1)  Material used to the PVC pipe, couplings and fittings shall conform to ASTM specification D1784, Class 12454-B. 
(2)  The standard dimensional ratio for the pipe shall be as follows: SDR 18 (Class 150). 
(Code 2008, § 13.04.116; Ord. No. 10-79, § 5, 1979) 
Sec. 74-170. - Building drain; procedure when drainage by gravity not possible. 
    In all buildings in which any building drain is too low to permit gravity flow to the public sewer, sanitary sewage carried by such drain shall be lifted by approved artificial means and discharged to the building sewer. 
(Code 2008, § 13.04.150; Ord. No. 260, § 409, 1952) 
Secs. 74-171-74-193. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - DISCHARGES, MAINTENANCE AND SAMPLING 

Sec. 74-194. - Use of the public sewers; prohibited discharges. 
    No person shall discharge, or cause to be discharged, any stormwater, surface water, groundwater, roof runoff, subsurface drainage, uncontaminated cooling water, or unpolluted industrial process waters to any sanitary sewer. 
(Code 2008, § 13.04.160; Ord. No. 11-83(part), 1983) 
Sec. 74-195. - Drainage waters; discharge into storm sewer, natural outlet required. 
    Stormwater and all other unpolluted drainage shall be discharged to such sewers as are specifically designated as combined sewers or storm sewers, or to a natural outlet approved by the city. Industrial cooling water or unpolluted process waters may be discharged on approval of the city, to a storm sewer, combined sewer, or natural outlet. 
(Code 2008, § 13.04.170; Ord. No. 11-83(part), 1983) 
Sec. 74-196. - Discharge of designated waters and wastes to public sewers prohibited. 
    No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged any of the following described waters or wastes to any public sewers: 
(1)  Any gasoline; benzene, naphtha, fuel oil, or other flammable or explosive liquid, solid or gas. 
(2)  Any waters or wastes containing toxic or poisonous solids, liquids or gases in sufficient quantity, either singly or by interaction with other wastes, to injure or interfere with any sewage treatment process, constitute a hazard to humans or animals, create a public nuisance, or create any hazard in the receiving waters of the sewage treatment plant. 
(3)  Any waters or wastes having a pH lower than 5.5 or having any other corrosive property capable of causing damage or hazard to structures, equipment, and personnel of the sewage works. 
(4)  Solid or viscous substances in quantity or of such size capable of causing obstruction to the flow in sewers, or other interference with the proper operation of the sewage works, such as, but not limited to, ashes, cinders, sand, mud, straw, shavings, metal, glass, rags, feathers, tar, plastics, wood, un-ground garbage, whole blood, paunch manure, hair and fleshing, entrails and paper dishes, cups, milk containers, etc., either whole or ground by garbage grinders. 
(Code 2008, § 13.04.175; Ord. No. 11-83(part), 1983) 
Sec. 74-197. - Discharge of harmful substances prohibited. 
    No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged the following described substances, materials, waters or wastes if it appears likely in the opinion of the city that such wastes can harm either the sewers sewage treatment process or equipment; have an adverse effect on the receiving stream; or can otherwise endanger life, limb, public property or constitutes a nuisance. In forming this opinion as to the acceptability of these wastes, the administrator will give consideration to such factors as the quantities of subject wastes in relation to flows and velocities in the sewers, materials of construction of the sewers, nature of the sewage treatment process, capacity of the sewage treatment plant, degree of treat ability of wastes in the sewage treatment plant, and maximum limits established by regulatory agencies. The substances prohibited are: 
(1)  Any liquid or vapor having a temperature higher than 150 degrees Fahrenheit (65 degrees Celsius). 
(2)  Any waters or wastes containing toxic or poisonous materials; or oils, whether emulsified or not, in excess of 100 mg/l or containing substances which may solidify or become viscous at temperatures between 32 and 150 degrees Fahrenheit (0 and 65 degrees Celsius). 
(3)  Any garbage that has not been properly shredded. The installation and operation of any garbage grinder equipped with a motor of three-fourths horsepower (0.76 hp metric) or greater shall be subject to the review and approval of the city. 
(4)  Any waters or wastes containing strong acid, iron pickling wastes, or concentrated plating solution whether neutralized or not. 
(5)  Any waters or wastes containing iron, chromium, copper, zinc, or similar objectionable or toxic substances; or wastes exerting an excessive chlorine requirement, to such degree that any such material received in the composite sewage at the sewage treatment works exceeds the limits established by the city for such materials. 
(6)  Any waters or wastes containing phenols or other taste or odor-producing substances, in such concentrations exceeding limits which may be established by the city as necessary after treatment of the composite sewage, to meet the requirements of the state, federal, or other public agencies of jurisdiction for such discharge to the receiving waters. 
(7)  Any radioactive wastes or isotopes of such half-life or concentration as may exceed limits established by the city in compliance with applicable state or federal regulations. 
(8)  Any wastes or waters having a pH in excess of 9.5. 
(9)  Any mercury or any of its compounds in excess of 0.0005 mg/l as Hg at any time except as permitted by the city in compliance with applicable state and federal regulations. 
(10)  Any cyanide in excess of 0.025 mg/l at any time except as permitted by the city in compliance with applicable state and federal regulations. 
(11)  Materials which exert or cause: 
a.  Unusual concentrations of inert suspended solids (such as, but not limited to, Fuller's earth, lime slurries, and lime residues) or of dissolved solids (such as, but not limited to, sodium chloride and sodium sulfate); 
b.  Excessive discoloration (such as, but not limited to, dye wastes and vegetable tanning solutions); 
c.  Unusual BOD, chemical oxygen demand, or chlorine requirements in such quantities as to constitute a significant load on the average treatment works; 
d.  Unusual volume of flow or concentrations of wastes constituting slugs. 
(12)  Waters or wastes containing substances which are not amenable to treatment or reduction by the sewage treatment processes employed, or are amenable to treatment only to such degree that the sewage treatment plant effluent cannot meet the requirements of agencies having jurisdiction over discharge to the receiving waters. 
(Code 2008, § 13.04.180; Ord. No. 11-83(part), 1983) 
Sec. 74-198. - Substances subject to review, preliminary treatment. 
    If any waters or wastes are discharged or are proposed to be discharged to the public sewers, which waters contain the substances or possess the characteristics enumerated in section 74-197, and/or which are in violation of the standards for pretreatment provided in 40 CFR 403, June 26, 1978, and any amendments thereto, and which in the judgment of the city may have a deleterious effect upon the sewage works, processes, equipment, or receiving waters, or which otherwise create a hazard to life or constitute a public nuisance, the city may: 
(1)  Reject the wastes; 
(2)  Require pretreatment to an acceptable condition for discharge to the public sewers; 
(3)  Require control over the quantities and rates of discharge; and/or; 
(4)  Require payment to cover the added costs of handling and treating the wastes not covered by existing taxes or sewer charges, under the provisions of section 74-204. 
If the city permits the pretreatment or equalization of waste flows, the design and installation of the plants and equipment shall be subject to the review and approval of the city, and subject to the requirements of all applicable codes, ordinances and laws. 
(Code 2008, § 13.04.190; Ord. No. 11-83(part) 1983) 
Sec. 74-199. - Grease, oil and sand interceptors. 
    Grease, oil, and sand interceptors shall be provided when; in the opinion of the city they are necessary for the proper handling of liquid wastes containing grease in excessive amounts, or any flammable wastes, sand or other harmful ingredients; except that such interceptors shall not be required for private living quarters or dwelling units. All interceptors shall be of a type and capacity approved by the city, and shall be located as to be readily and easily accessible for cleaning and inspection. 
(Code 2008, § 13.04.200; Ord. No. 11-83(part), 1983) 
Sec. 74-200. - Preliminary treatment or flow equalizing facilities; maintenance. 
    Where preliminary treatment or flow equalizing facilities are provided; they shall be maintained continuously in satisfactory and effective operation by the owner at his expense. 
(Code 2008, § 13.04.205; Ord. No. 11-83(part), 1983) 
Sec. 74-201. - Manhole; requirement; maintenance. 
    Each industry shall be required to install a control manhole and, when required by the city, the owner of any property serviced by a building sewer carrying industrial wastes shall install a suitable control manhole together with such necessary meters and other appurtenances in the building sewer to facilitate observation, sampling, and measurement of the wastes. Such manhole, when required, shall be accessibly and safely located, and shall be constructed in accordance with plans approved by the city. The manhole shall be installed by the owner at his expense, and shall be maintained by him so as to be safe and accessible at all times. 
(Code 2008, § 13.04.210; Ord. No. 11-83(part), 1983) 
Sec. 74-202. - Measurements of waters and wastes; required. 
    The owner of any property serviced by a building sewer carrying industrial wastes shall provide laboratory measurements, test, and analysis of waters and wastes to illustrate compliance with the ordinance codified herein and any special conditions for discharge established by the city or regulatory agencies having jurisdiction over the discharge. The number, type and frequency of laboratory analysis to be performed by the owner shall be as stipulated by the city, but no less than once per year the industry must supply a complete analysis of the constituents of the wastewater discharge to assure that compliance with the federal, state, and local standards are being met. The owner shall report the results of measurements and laboratory analysis to the city at such times and in such a manner as prescribed by the city. The owner shall bear the expense of all measurements, analysis and reporting required by the city. At such times as deemed necessary the city reserves the right to take measurements and samples for analysis by an outside laboratory service. 
(Code 2008, § 13.04.215; Ord. No. 11-83(part), 1983) 
Sec. 74-203. - Sampling; where taken from; methods. 
    All measurements, tests and analysis of the characteristics of waters and wastes to which reference is made in the ordinance codified herein shall be determined in accordance with the latest edition of IEPA Division of Laboratories Manual of Laboratory Methods, and shall be determined at the control manhole provided, or upon suitable samples taken at the control manhole. In the event that no special manhole has been required the control manhole shall be considered to be the nearest downstream manhole in the public sewer to the point at which the building sewer is connected. Sampling shall be carried out by customarily accepted methods to reflect the effect of constituents upon the sewage works and to determine the existence of hazards to life, limb, and property. The particular analysis involved will determine whether a 24-hour composite of all outfalls of a premises is appropriate or whether a grab sample or samples should be taken. Normally, but not always, BOD and suspended solids analysis are obtained from 24-hour composites of all outfalls, whereas pH's are determined from periodic grab samples. 
(Code 2008, § 13.04.220; Ord. No. 11-83(part), 1983) 
Sec. 74-204. - Provisions not to prevent special agreements. 
    No statement contained in this section and sections 74-194 through 74-203 shall be construed as preventing any special agreement or arrangement between the city and any industrial concern whereby an industrial waste of unusual strength or character may be accepted by the city for treatment, subject to payment therefor, in accordance with sections 74-418 through 74-426, by the industrial concern provided such payments are in accordance with federal and state guide lines for user charge system. 
(Code 2008, § 13.04.230; Ord. No. 11-83(part), 1983) 
Sec. 74-205. - Interceptors; maintenance responsibility. 
    Where installed, all grease, oil and sand interceptors shall be maintained by the owner, at his expense, in continuously efficient operation at all times. 
(Code 2008, § 13.04.250; Ord. No. 260, § 505, 1952) 
Secs. 74-206-74-233. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - REGULATIONS FOR WATER SERVICE 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 74-234-74-259. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CONNECTIONS 

Sec. 74-260. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    City water main means all waterlines that convey water to two or more properties within the corporate limits of the city. 
    Dwelling unit means one or more rooms constituting all or part of a dwelling which are used exclusively as living quarters for one family. 
    Private service line means the water supply line extending from the water main to the building served. 
    Private water main means any waterline that conveys water to two or more properties outside the corporate limits of the city. 
    Shutoff valve means a city main or service line with a valve box to be operated from above ground. 
(Code 2008, § 13.08.010; Ord. No. 1-87, § 1, 1987) 
Sec. 74-261. - Connecting water mains to city water systems. 
    Any person, firm or corporation connecting a water main to the city water system shall pay all the costs of the water main and service connections necessary to accomplish such connection from an existing city water main of sufficient size to support the additional demand unless explicitly authorized by the city council, and the same shall be done under the supervision of and subject to the approval of the city administrator or his designated representative. 
(Code 2008, § 13.08.020; Ord. No. 1-87, § 2, 1987) 
Sec. 74-262. - Connecting service lines to city water system. 
(a)  No connection to a city water main shall be made without a permit being issued and 48 hours' notice, consisting of two full working days, having been given to the city. All such connections shall be made and all such work done at the expense of the applicant who shall also furnish all materials necessary for such work. 
(b)  The water meter shall be purchased from the city and the city water main shall be tapped by the city. All such connections shall be made under the supervision of authorized city personnel and no connections shall be covered until the work has been inspected by a city designated representative. 
(c)  Applications for such connections must be made to the city. 
(d)  All service lines must be of copper or polyethylene 200 PSI with tracer wire attached, must be buried a minimum of four feet below ground level and must be equipped with a shut off valve that is operable. Any service line serving more than one dwelling-unit must be equipped with a shut off valve, accessible from outside the building, for each individual meter, and no service line for any building shall be permitted to cross any lot or building to serve an adjoining lot or building. 
(e)  Excavations to be guarded with barricades. All excavations for connections to water main shall be adequately guarded with barricades and lights so as to protect the public from hazard. Streets, sidewalks, parkways, and other public property disturbed in the course of the work shall be restored in a manner satisfactory to the city. 
(Code 2008, § 13.08.030; Ord. No. 1-87, § 3, 1987; Ord. No. 15-17, § I, 8-17-2015) 
Sec. 74-263. - Tapping. 
    All city water mains will be tapped by the city. It shall be the responsibility of the owner of the private water main or private service line to excavate the city water main and provide sufficient working space, as determined by the director of public works or his designated representative, to make the tap. The city will then tap the city water main and install a shutoff valve on the private water main or private service line as close to the city water main as possible. Tapping fees are as follows: 
(1)  Three-quarter-inch: $400.00. 
(2)  One-inch through 11/4-inch: $400.00. 
(3)  11/2-inch through two-inch: $500.00. 
These fees cover all labor and materials for the work per formed by the city. 
(Code 2008, § 13.08.040; Ord. No. 1-87, § 5, 1987; Ord. No. 2-93, § 4, 1993) 
Sec. 74-264. - Hookup fee. 
    There will be a hookup fee of $250.00 for each new private service line connected to the city water main. This fee is separate from the tapping fee. No hookup fee will be charged on a new private service line which is replacing an old private service line. 
(Code 2008, § 13.08.050; Ord. No. 1-87, § 6, 1987) 
Sec. 74-265. - Property owner's responsibilities for paying. 
    Whenever a bill for water or sewer services remains unpaid for 45 days after it has been rendered, the administrative office staff shall send to the owner of record of the real estate: 
(1)  A copy of each delinquent notice sent to the person who is delinquent in paying the charges or rates or other notice sufficient to inform the owner of record of said real estate the charges or rates have become delinquent. 
(2)  If a real estate property is used for rental or lease and the water or sewer account is delinquent for three consecutive billing periods, the property owner of record will be notified that the metered water usage will become the responsibility of the property owner of record in 15 days of the date of written notice from the city to the property owner of record. The city will insure that the meter will be read on the effective date of the transfer of the account as specified in the written notification. Should the owner of the property become delinquent for water metered following the effective date of the transfer of the water account, a lien may be placed on the property. The property owner of record shall not be held responsible for prior water or sewer delinquent accounts incurred by occupants/tenants, unless otherwise assumed by the landlord (owner) through a waiver of deposit agreement. 
(3)  If a shut-off valve is inoperable or non-existent the administrative staff shall notify the city maintenance department to repair, replace or install a workable outside shutoff. If a property with one or more living units, the owner must provide an outside shut off for each living unit. The city will maintain and/or repair the shut off after its installation. 
(Code 2008, § 13.08.060; Ord. No. 1-87, § 4, 1987; Ord. No. 19-01, § 2, 2001) 
Sec. 74-266. - Repairs to private service lines and private water main meters. 
    All private service lines within the corporate limits of the city shall be repaired and maintained, from the shut off valve including the meter pit and meter to the property residence, user or building served. The city will maintain all one-half inch and three-fourths inch water meters at no charge and will provide for the maintenance of all meters larger than three-fourths inch for which the property owner will be charged an amount equivalent to the costs incurred by the city. 
(Code 2008, § 13.08.070; Ord. No. 1-87, § 6, 1987; Ord. No. 11-04, § I, 3-21-2011) 
Sec. 74-267. - Repairs to and metered connections of private water mains and private service lines. 
    All private water mains shall be repaired and maintained, from the city water main to their termination, by the users of the city water furnished thereby and the city shall have no responsibility for the repair and maintenance of any such private water mains or required meters or meter pits. 
(1)  All private water mains shall at the point of connection to the city water main have installed a meter pit with an approved meter and remote read register to record the usage on the private water main. 
(2)  Any private water main or service water line with a length greater than 150 feet from the city water main shall be metered and billed at the point of connection of the private water main or service line to the city water main. 
(3)  The remote read register on the pit meter shall be read each month at the same time as the home meter(s) connected by private service lines to the private water main. 
(4)  The total monthly usage shown on the pit meter shall be compared to the combined monthly usage of the homeowner connected to the private water main. 
(5)  All usage recorded on the pit meter in excess of the combined usage of the homeowner(s)connected to the private water main by a private service line shall be billed at the current water rate to each homeowner an equal share of the total usage recorded. 
(Code 2008, § 13.08.080; Ord. No. 11-04, § I, 3-21-2011) 
Sec. 74-268. - Abandoned private water mains and service lines. 
    Any person, firm or corporation who abandons a private water main or service line shall excavate such abandoned line at its juncture with the city water main, cut off the abandoned line and close the corporation stop on the city water main or, in the absence of a corporation stop, cap the abandoned line where it leaves the city water main. This work must be inspected and approved by the city director of public works or his designated representative. 
(Code 2008, § 13.08.090; Ord. No. 1-87, § 8, 1987) 
Sec. 74-269. - Application to turn water on. 
    Application to have water turned on shall be made at the office of the city clerk. 
(Code 2008, § 13.08.100; Ord. No. 1-87, § 10, 1987) 
Sec. 74-270. - Turning water on. 
    No water from the city water system shall be turned on for service into any premises by any person but the water plant operator in charge or his designated representative. All tapping fees, hookup fees, deposits and past due accounts of the user must be paid in full before the water is turned on. 
(Code 2008, § 13.08.110; Ord. No. 1-87, § 11, 1987) 
Sec. 74-271. - Resale and/or distribution. 
    No water shall be resold or distributed by the recipient thereof from the city supply to any premises other than that for which application has been made and the meter installed, nor after water is introduced into any building or upon any premises shall any person make or employ any other person to make any tap, or connection with the work upon the premises for alterations, repairs, extensions or attachments without a written permit therefor to be issued by the city council, except in case of an emergency. 
(Code 2008, § 13.08.120; Ord. No. 1-87, § 12, 1987) 
Sec. 74-272. - Tampering. 
    It is unlawful for any person not authorized by the city to tamper with, alter or injure any part of the city water works or supply system or any water meter. 
(Code 2008, § 13.08.130; Ord. No. 1-87, § 13, 1987) 
Sec. 74-273. - Connections outside the city. 
    It is illegal to connect any private or other water system to the city water system, either directly or indirectly, or to connect the same to the water lines in or on any person's or corporation's property, if such lines are connected to the city water distribution system. 
(Code 2008, § 13.08.140; Ord. No. 1-87, § 14, 1987) 
Secs. 74-274-74-294. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - RULES AND REGULATIONS 

Sec. 74-295. - Unpaid bills to become a lien; notice. 
    Pursuant to section 74-265, all unpaid account balances that remain unpaid 45 days after it is rendered, the city administrative staff shall send to the owner or owners of record a notice of delinquency. If the bill for water or sewer service remains unpaid 15 days after such notice has been delivered, the city administrative staff shall file with the county recorder of deeds a sworn statement of lien claim. A lien notification will be sent under the described following conditions: 
(1)  The legal description of the premises served; 
(2)  The total dollar amount of the amount billed, including any additional amounts incurred by the city as a result of the lien, including attorney fees and recording costs; 
(3)  The date when the amount became delinquent; and 
(4)  A notice that the city claims a lien for the amount as well as for all charges subsequent to the period covered by the bill. 
(Code 2008, § 13.08.160; Ord. No. 19-01, § 3, 2001) 
Sec. 74-296. - Foreclosure of lien. 
    Any lien filed pursuant to sections 74-265 and 74-295 may be foreclosed by the city in accordance with the law. The proceeds of the sale shall be applied to pay the charges together with any other costs, including attorney's fees incurred by the city, made by such foreclosure. The city attorney is authorized and directed to institute such proceedings in the name of the city in any court having jurisdiction over such matters against any property for which the bill has remained unpaid 60 days after it has been rendered. 
(Code 2008, § 13.08.170; Ord. No. 19-01, § 3, 2001) 
Sec. 74-297. - Control and supervision of water systems. 
    There is established an executive department of the city to be known as the "water department." The city council authorized the establishment by ordinance of an enterprise committee to have general control and supervision of the water department. The city council is authorized to appoint a superintendent of the water and have the general management and control of the waterworks system subject, however to the supervision of the city council. 
(Code 2008, § 13.08.200) 
Sec. 74-298. - Unlawful obstructions. 
(a)  No person shall in any manner obstruct the access to any stopcock, hydrant or valve, or any public faucet or opening for taking water in any street, alley, public ground or place connected with or part of the water system, nor pile or place any lumber, brick or building material or other article, thing or hindrance whatsoever within 12 feet of the same, or so as to in any manner hinder, delay or obstruct the members of the fire department in reaching the same. It is unlawful for any person in any manner to interfere with or obstruct the flow, retention, storage or authorized use of water in the water system, reservoir, or plant, or any part thereof, or to injure, deface, remove or displace any water main, hydrant, service pipe, shutoff box, public fountain, valve, engine or building connected with the water system, or plant, or to cause, suffer or permit any of such things to be done. 
(b)  Any person who shall perform any act in violation of this section shall upon conviction thereof be fined in accordance with section 1-8 for each offense, and shall in addition be liable for the actual damage done or caused. 
(Code 2008, § 13.08.210; Ord. No. 200, § 3, 1940) 
Sec. 74-299. - Unauthorized use of water from fire hydrant or service codecock. 
    No person not duly authorized shall turn the water on at any fire hydrant or service cock, or use water there from when so turned on, and the person so using or wasting water in such unlawful manner shall be liable to pay for the same. 
(Code 2008, § 13.08.220; Ord. No. 200, § 4, 1941) 
Sec. 74-300. - City not liable for damages or injury. 
    All connections and water applied for under this chapter, and all the water used hereunder, shall be upon the express condition that the city shall not be liable, nor shall any claim be made against it for damages or injury caused by reason of the breaking of any main, branches, service pipes, apparatus or appurtenances connected with the system or plant, or any part or portion of the plant, or for any interruption of the supply by reason of the breakage of machinery, or by reason of stoppage, alterations, extensions or renewals. 
(Code 2008, § 13.08.230; Ord. No. 200, § 5, 1941) 
Sec. 74-301. - Right of city of shut off water. 
    The city reserves the right to shut off water at any time in the mains for the purpose of repairing, cleaning, making connections with or extensions to same, or for the concentrating of water in any part of the city in case of fire; and for restricting the use of the water in case of deficiency in supply. No claim shall be made against the city by reason of the breaking of any service pipe or service cock, or damage arising from shutting off of water for repairing, laying or relaying mains, hydrants or other connections or repairing any part of the water system, or from failure of the water supply, or by increasing the water pressure at any time, or from concentration or restricted use of water as above. 
(Code 2008, § 13.08.270; Ord. No. 200, § 9(3), 1941) 
Sec. 74-302. - Violation of rules and nonpayment of bills; turning off water. 
    For violation of any of the rules set forth in section 74-301, the city reserves the right to turn off the water, upon five days' notice and to forfeit any payments made, and after the water has been turned off from any service pipe on account of nonpayment of water bills, or violation of rules, the same will not be turned on until all delinquent bills and penalties are paid, together with expense of turning off and on such water, as set out in article IV of this chapter. 
(Code 2008, § 13.08.280; Ord. No. 10-85(part), 1985; Ord. No. 200, § 10, 1941) 
Sec. 74-303. - Suspension of service for fountains and sprinkling. 
    The right is reserved to suspend the use of lawn fountains and hose for sprinkling lawns and gardens whenever in the opinion of the city council public emergency require it. 
(Code 2008, § 13.08.310; Ord. No. 200, § 12, 1941) 
Secs. 74-304-74-324. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - USE OF PUBLIC AND PRIVATE WATER SUPPLIES 

Sec. 74-325. - Use of publicly regulated water system required. 
    No person owning or occupying any property within the city shall utilize any source of water for human consumption or for household, commercial or industrial purposes other than an available publicly regulated water system, except for purposes of irrigation. For purposes of this section, the term "available publicly regulated water system" means, with respect to a given parcel, any water main located within 200 feet of any property line describing a lot or tract, which water main delivers water supplied by the municipal water system operated by the city, water supplied by any public water district, or water supplied by any community well existing as of March 1, 2004, which well is both subject to the jurisdiction of the environmental protection agency and operated in accordance with the rules and regulations promulgated or enforced by the state environmental protection agency. 
(Code 2008, § 13.08.320; Ord. No. 7-04, § 2(part), 2004) 
Sec. 74-326. - Limitations on construction of private water wells. 
    Except as hereinafter provided, no person shall drill, dig, drive, or otherwise construct any private water well of any nature whatsoever in that area within the corporate limits of the city which is serviced by the municipal water system operated by the city. For purposes of this section, the term "private water well" means any water well constructed by any person or entity other than the city. 
(Code 2008, § 13.08.330; Ord. No. 7-04, § 2(part), 2004) 
Sec. 74-327. - Variances authorizing the construction of private water wells. 
    Where no available publicly regulated water system exists, the city council may, by resolution, authorize the construction of private water well, but only if all of the following conditions have been met: 
(1)  The site of the private water well does not lie within 1,000 feet of any potential source of contamination by any hazardous or special waste; and 
(2)  The private water well is constructed in accordance with all applicable laws or regulations, including, without limitation, the following, as they now exist or may from time to time be amended: 
a.  The Illinois Water Well Construction Code, Illinois Laws and Compiled Statutes, chapter 415, section 30 (415 ILCS 30 et seq.); 
b.  The Illinois Water Well Pump Installation Code, Illinois Laws and Compiled Statutes, chapter 415, section 35 (415 ILCS 35 et seq.); 
c.  The Illinois Water Well and Pump Installation Contractor's License Act, Illinois Laws and Compiled Statutes, chapter 225, section 345 (225 ILCS 345 et seq.); 
d.  Environmental Protection Act, Illinois Laws and Compiled Statutes, chapter 415, section 5 (415 ILCS et seq.); and 
e.  Illinois Water Well Construction Code, 77 Ill. Admin. Code 920.10 et seq.) and Illinois Water Well Pump Installation Code, 77 Ill. Admin. Code 925.10 et seq.). 
(Code 2008, § 13.08.340; Ord. No. 7-04, § 2(part), 2004) 
Sec. 74-328. - Potable water supply by the installation or use of potable water. 
(a)  The use of groundwater as a potable water supply is prohibited. The use or attempt to use as a potable water supply groundwater from within Lots 1, 2, 3, and 4 in Block 13 of the city by the installation or drilling of wells or by any other method is hereby prohibited. This prohibition applies to the current common addresses of 104, 106, 112, 114, 116, 118, and 120 South Main Street, Eureka, Illinois. The permanent index numbers for the affected properties are as follows: 
(1)  13-12-436-004. 
(2)  13-12-436-005. 
(3)  13-12-436-006. 
(4)  13-12-436-007. 
(5)  13-12-436-008.
